comments.rationale: FSN-1 is expressed specifically in the nervous system in the nerve processes. At the synapse, FSN-1 is excluded from the active zone because it does not localize with active-zone protein UNC-10. It is present at some periactive zones because it resides adjacent to the vesicle region and partly overlaps with RPM-1, which is restricted to periactive zones. At GABAergic NMJs, FSN-1 is absent from the postsynaptic terminal.

Hirobumi Tada"

comments.rationale:
Double mutant mice of (i) hypomorph HYH (recessive missense mutation (M105I)in alpha-SNAP)a dn (ii) beta-SNAP KO show 25% reduced RRP size as determined by HSS stimulation without changes in evoked EPSC amplitudes or mEPSC amplitudes and frequencies. EPSC recovery after electrical discharge of the RRP by long 40 Hz and 100 Hz AP trains was slower in DKO neurons as compared to Ctrl cells.

8/12/2016 Pim
- hypomorph HYH reduces the amount of aSNAP and is embryonically lethal
- Syn.Tr. in  hypomorph HYH aSNAP mouse is unaltered.
- Syn.Tr. in bSNAP mouse is unaltered.
- aSNAP and bSNAP are functionally interchangable (also shown in Fig 7)
- In the Dmut mouse bSNAP is completely removed and aSNAP is present at reduced levels
- The results in the Dmut mouse should be attributed to reduction of aSNAP

comments.rationale: Snapin facilitates the synchronization of synaptic vesicle fusion. Snapin null mutant mice show reduced frequency of miniature excitatory postsynaptic currents (mini-EPSCs) and smaller release-ready vesicle pool (RRP) size (Fig.1), snapin deficiency results in EPSCs with multiple peaks and increased rise and decay times, reflecting "desynchronized" SV fusion (Fig.3).

comments.species: Double and single immunofluorescence labelling of cryostat sections from rat spinal cord and bovine retinae was performed27 with two independent polyclonal Rim antibodies and multiple monoclonal antibodies to synaptic vesicle proteins.
comments.rationale: This publication demonstrates with immuno-EM and immunofluorescence that RIM1 is specifically localized at the active zone in spinal cord and ribbon synapses. It makes use of two separate antibodies, plus additional controls (including secondary only). No knockout control is provided.

comments.species: High-density hippocampal cultures were prepared from newborn mice and infected with lentiviruses as described (Kaeser et al., 2009).
comments.rationale: RIM1/RIM2 double knockout cultures have a reduction in the size of the sucrose pool at inhibitory synapses, demonstrating a role for RIM proteins in vesicle priming (fig 1c). This is mediated by activation of Munc13 through the Zinc finger domain (figures 3,4 5 and 6). Due to the strong homology between RIM1 and RIM2, both proteins are assumed to be redundant in this process. Action potential mediated pool measurements have confirmed a role in priming at the calyx of Held (Han et.al. 2011), and sucrose pool measurements in cultured neurons have confirmed this role at excitatory synapses (Kaeser et.al. 2011).

comments.species: We cultured neurons from newborn conditional double KO mice and infected these neurons with lentiviruses expressing EGFP-tagged active or inactive cre-recombinases.
comments.rationale: In cultured RIM1/RIM2 double knockout neurons, there is an about 40% reduction in the number of docked vesicles, as measured by electron microscopy in glutaraldehyde fixed cultures.

comments.species: Our S‐synaptosome preparation was adapted from two previously published protocols (Hebb & Whittaker, 1958; Huttner et al, 1983). Briefly, forebrains of one or two mice were homogenized in 4 ml of ice‐cold homogenization buffer (0.32 M Sucrose, 4 mM HEPES pH 7.4, 1 μM PMSF, 1 μg/ml Aprotinin, 1 μg/ml Leupeptin) using a 5‐ml glass‐Teflon homogenizer with 12 gentle strokes.
comments.rationale: The authors used synaptosomes derived from vGlut-Venus knockin mice to enrich for glutamatergic presynaptic terminals. Mass spectrometry was performed to detect protein content, which identified PPM1H. Although this method favors the detection of presynaptic proteins, postsynaptic or extrasynaptic localization of PPM1H cannot be excluded with this method.

comments.rationale:
Using an PKC-gamma specific antibody with knock out control, it is demonstrated that PKC gamma is expressed in the presynaptic terminal of the Calyx of Held.

comments.species: PKCγ KO mice (Abeliovich et al., 1993) were obtained from Jackson Laboratory.
comments.rationale: It is demonstrated that PKC gamma controls post-tetanic potentiation in the juvenile calyx of Held. Since it does not regulate pool size (figure 5) or calcium influx (figure 6), it must regulate the probability of Ca2+-dependent fusion.

comments.species: In slices from wild-type mice, antibody labeling for PKCα and PKCβ overlapped with vGlut1 labeling, consistent with presynaptic localization of these kinases at the calyx of Held synapse.
comments.rationale:
Using a PKC alpha specific antibody and knockout control, it is demonstrated that PKC alpha is expressed at the presynaptic terminal of the calyx of held.

10/3/2017 Pim:
-Literal: "In slices from wild-type mice, antibody labeling for PKCα and PKCβ overlapped with vGlut1 labeling, consistent with presynaptic localization of these kinases at the calyx of Held synapse."
-PCKalpha has C2 domain and is able to interact with lipids membranes. In previous annotations of this expert it was established that only a small fraction of the total PKC pool is membrane attached; the rest resides in the cytoplasm. Therefore, the "cytosol" component of the term is inferred. Because domain information is not reflected in GO, I agreed to this term.

comments.species: Robust PTP was observed in wild-type mice. (...) Representative experiments show that somewhat smaller PTP was observed in PKCα−/− animals (Figure 2B), and PTP was greatly reduced in PKCβ−/− (Figure 2C) and PKCα−/−β−/− mice (Figure 2D).
comments.rationale:
It is demonstrated that a PKC alpha knockout has a reduction in post-tetanic potentiation (PTP), in the Calyx of Held. It is also shown that PTP operates at least partly due to a potentiation in readily releasable pool size, and that this potentiation is diminished in the PKC alpha/beta knockout. 

It should be noted that in some synapses, PKC alpha is not required for PTP (Wang et.al. 2016).

comments.species: Robust PTP was observed in wild-type mice. (...) Representative experiments show that somewhat smaller PTP was observed in PKCα−/− animals (Figure 2B), and PTP was greatly reduced in PKCβ−/− (Figure 2C) and PKCα−/−β−/− mice (Figure 2D).
comments.rationale:
It is demonstrated that a PKC beta knockout abolishes post-tetanic potentiation (PTP), in the Calyx of Held. It is also shown that PTP operates at least partly due to a potentiation in readily releasable pool size, and that this potentiation is lost in the PKC alpha/beta knockout.

It should be noted that at some synapses, PKC beta is not required for PTP (Wang et.al. 2016).

comments.species: Dissociated hippocampal neurons from E18 SD rats of both sexes were prepared as described previously31.
comments.rationale:
Using STORM super resolution microscopy and well-validated antibodies, it is demonstrated that RIM1/2 is localized at the active zone, directly opposed to PSD95. RIM1/2 localization is very similar to other well-validated active zone components, including Munc13 and Bassoon (Figure 1). RIM1/2 localization is also shown to correlate with the location of vesicle fusion (Figure 2).

23/01/2017 Pim
- The RIM antibody (anti-RIM1/2 (1:500; Synaptic Systems No. 140203) used in Fig. 1 has a non-selective RIM1/RIM2 specificity.
- The authors mention identical results with a RIM1 specific antibody ("Similar distribution and nanocluster properties were found using a different antibody targeted towards a separate epitope in RIM1 (Extended Data Fig. 2d)").
- presynaptic localization of overexpressed RIM1 is shown in Fig.2 ("To assess these predictions, we mapped vesicle fusion sites relative to Eos3-tagged RIM1 using sequential PALM-pHuse imaging on the same live boutons (Fig. 2h, Extended Data Fig. 6d, e)")
- Overall these data justify annotation against RIM1.

comments.species: Brains of adult C57/BL6 mice of mixed sex were used in all biochemical experiments and for preparation of brain slices
comments.rationale:
Using two different antibodies in immunofluorescence and immuno-electron microscopy it is shown that CtBP2 is present in the presynaptic cytosol at synapses in the cerebellum. Although the antibodies do not discriminate between different gene products of CtBP2, the gene product RIBEYE was not detected in brain lysates. It is thus assumed that the detected protein is CtBP2 or CtBP2-S.

13.3.2017 Pim:
- Literal: "To this end we utilized antibodies specific to either CtBP1 or CtBP2. The antibodies did, however, recognize all isoforms known to date expressed from the individual genes. However, as the specific antibody to ribbon-specific CtBP2 variant RIBEYE did not show any signal in homogenates from whole brain (data not shown), the signals described here are most likely derived from the long and short isoforms of CtBP1 and CtBP2."

comments.species: Immunogold electron microscopy was performed largely as previously described (Schmitz and Drenckhahn 1993). Bovine retina fixed with 2% freshly depolymerized paraformaldehyde, 0.1% glutaraldehyde in PBS for 3 hr at 4°C were washed with PBS (six times, each for 10 min) and infiltrated with 0.5% tannic acid (Mallinckrodt) in PBS (1 hr at 4°C).
comments.rationale: Using immuno electron microscopy, it is demonstrated that RIBEYE is specifically located in the ribbon of the ribbon synapse.

nally, the avidin-biotin-peroxidase complex was added to
the sections (1:100).

comments.rationale:
Localizing Piccolo/Aczonin using multiple antibodies covering the entire length of Piccolo/Aczonin by Immunogold technology to the active zone of cerebellar synapses. The paper describes the orientation relative to the synaptic membrane and compares it to the localization of other proteins including Bassoon, ELKS/CAST, RIM and Munc13. 
Supporting evidence shows the localization of the protein to other glutamatergic synapses in the hippocampus as well as retinal photoreceptor ribbon synapses.

comments.rationale: The paper summarizes the evidence from many original reports. comments.rationale:
Fig.7: Immunoperoxidase electron microscopical localisation of Caldendrin in rat cerebral cortex. In the parietal cortex (A–C) cytoplasmic labeling was frequently observed in large to small dendritic pro files (d in A) throughout the cortical layers (see light microscopical results). In synaptic areas, caldendrin immunoreactivity in different cortical layers was exclusively localised postsynaptically (see arrows) in asymmetrical glutamatergic synapses. Labeled synapses (arrows) were either large, complex synapses (A and B), or smaller spine synapses (C). Note that immunopositive  synapses  are  found  in  close  neighbourhood  together  with  unlabeled  synapses  of  the  same  morphological  type  (marked  by asterisks).  (D)  In  immunopositive  putative  interneuron  dendrites  (receiving  several  asymmetrical  synapses)  the  DAB  reaction  product  displayed — in contrast to all other examples shown—no tendency of being distributed toward the postsynaptic densities asterisks). (E) Occasionally,  two  synapses  on  the  same  target  structure  and  in  close  neighbourhood  were  observed  to  be  immunopositive  and  immunonegative,
respectively, for caldendrin. The survey micrograph (G) of caldendrin-IR in the cortex shows that in close neighbourhood to the relatively rarely occurring immunopositive synapses (arrow) many immunonegative synapses (asterisks) can be found. The appearance (staining) of postsynaptic densities in immunonegative synapses (A, B, D, E, G) was similar when comparing them to material obtained from negative controls, which were not incubated with the primary antibody (F).

comments.rationale: RIM2 knockout cultures have a reduction in the size of the sucrose pool at inhibitory synapses, demonstrating a role for RIM2 in vesicle priming.  Due to the strong homology between RIM1 and RIM2, both proteins are assumed to be redundant in this process. Action potential mediated pool measurements have confirmed a role in priming for RIM1 and RIM2 at the Calyx of Held (Han et.al. 2011).

comments.species: We cultured neurons from newborn conditional double KO mice and infected these neurons with lentiviruses expressing EGFP-tagged active or inactive cre-recombinases.
comments.rationale: In cultured RIM1/RIM2 double knockout neurons, there is an about 40% reduction in the number of docked vesicles, as measured by electron microscopy in glutaradehyde fixed cultures. Due to their high homology, the synaptic functions of RIM1 and RIM2 are assumed to be redundant (Han 2015).

comments.species: 30-d-old male rats were used for immunohistochemical studies. Tissue preparation for electron microscopic analysis was done as described by Richter et al. (1996).
comments.rationale: Using immunofluorescence and immuno electron microscopy it is shown that Bassoon is present at the presynaptic active zone. As controls for the immuno electron microscopy, stainings without primary antibody were performed. Hallerman et.al. 2014 provides an knockout control for the antibody. This antibody (sap7f) is a widely used marker for the active zone.

comments.species: Mutant mice carrying a gene-trapped allele of the Bassoon gene were derived from Omnibank ES cell line OST486029 by Lexicon Pharmaceuticals, Inc. (The Woodlands, TX).
comments.rationale: The cerebellar mossy fiber to granule cell synapse was used to study the role of Bassoon in synaptic transmission. It is shown that Bassoon knockout cells have an increased synaptic depression during intense stimulation, and subsequent reduction in the recovery from depression. This suggest a defect in vesicle replenishment.  A similar phenotype was reported using a partial Bassoon knockout in ribbon synapses (Frank et.al. 2010) and the endbulb of Held (Mendoza Schulz et .al. 2014). It is currently unknown what stage of the synaptic vesicle cycle is affected by Bassoon knockout.

comments.species: "Mice lacking type1 InsP3Rs and wild-type littermates (20–23 days) were anaesthetized..."
comments.rationale:
To study synaptic plasticity, the authors correlated pre- and postsynaptic activation using a train of stimuli (16s, 5 Hz) delivered to one Schaffer collateral/commissural input that was paired with a postsynaptic injection of a spike-inducing depolarizing current. Two conditions were studied: (1) when the onset of EPSPs was about 20 ms after postsynaptic spiking, the EPSC amplitude of both stimulated (homosynaptic) and non-stimulated (heterosynaptic) inputs showed a persistent reduction following the correlated activation (LTD protocol) and (2) when the onset of EPSPs was about 5 ms before postsynaptic spiking, the EPSC amplitude of the homosynaptic input showed a persistent increase in amplitude whereas the one of the heterosynaptic input was not affected (LTP protocol).

Functional blockade of IP3R1 by postsynaptic loading of a monoclonal antibody against IP3R1 or genetic deletion of IP3R1 using IP3R1-deficient mice impacted both conditions: when studying LTD (1) lacking IP3R1 function led to a conversion of homosynaptic LTD to LTP and eliminated heterosynaptic LTD. When studying LTP (2) a significant enhancement of homosynaptic LTP was observed, resulting in even higher potentiation. Therefore, IP3R1 presents a role in regulating Ca2+ release from internal stores in the postsynaptic neuron, which can control polarity and magnitude of postsynaptic plasticity.

comments.rationale:
Fig 2: SV2A/B deficiency causes a decrease in evoked responses induced by isolated action potentials without a change in mini frequency, mini amplitude, apparent Ca2+ sensitivity of release, or the size of the RRP. Fig3: no difference between synapses lacking only SV2B or both SV2A and SV2B in the size of the ionomycin-releasable RRP or the kinetics of ionomycin-induced release. Hence, SV2 acts at a novel step in synaptic vesicle exocytosis that renders primed vesicles Ca2+ responsive.

-The effect of SV2A is derived from comparisons of SV2B and SV2A/B double KO animals; any difference between these two strains is caused by function of SV2A (see comment expert above)

comments.rationale:
Flot1 is required for PKC-triggered internalization and Amphiphysin-induced reverse transport of DA in primary DA neurons. It is essential for membrane microdomain localization of dopamine transporter.

20/2/2017 Pim
-primary paper: Flot1 is required for PKC-triggered internalization and Amphiphysin-induced reverse transport of DA in primary DA neuron. This role at the level of the synapse is not shown.
-SynGO ID #201: Flot1 is localized in synapses of hippocamal neurons. Pre or postsynaptic localization cannot be distinguished based on the presented data.
-Inference: Flot1 regulates "NT reuptake" in the synapse.

8/8/2017 Pim
- On second thought I have agreed for the term 'neurotransmitter reuptake (GO:0098810). Flot1 is shown to mediate PKC-triggered internalization and Amphiphysin-induced reverse transport of DA in primary DA neurons. According to SynGO guidelines this does not have to happen AT the synapse; BPs are included when relevant for synaptic function. Without evidence shown this is implied by the authors "Plasmalemmal neurotransmitter transporters (NTTs) regulate the level of neurotransmitters, such as dopamine (DA) and glutamate, after their release at brain synapses". Another point of doubt is the 're-' part of the term 'reuptake'. No experiments are shown in a synaptic context and secretion from synapses and consecutive re-uptake are not shown in the paper. I have allowed this under an IC evidence type: the justification here is that whatever Dopamine is around cells that this has to be secreted by a synapse at some time.

comments.rationale: Analyses of highly purified synaptic vesicles by mass spectrometry indicates that Rab8B co-purifiies with synaptic vesicles. However, using the distribution of EGFP-Rab8B in hippocampal neurons as visualised by immunofluorescence microscopy does not support enrichment on synaptic vesicles. Together with results from Takamori et al and Wilhelm et al, this suggests that Rab8B is present at presynaptic terminals but not on synaptic vesicles.

comments.rationale:
Quantitative mass spectrometry and immunoblotting of highly purified synaptic vesicles from the rat brain indicate that Rab6a copurifies with synaptic vesicles.

The SV/homogenate enrichment ratios of Rab6A and 6B are 1.68 (WB) and 2.59 and 3.37 (iTRAQ), respectively in the Pavlos paper. However, no co-localisation of either rabs with synaptophysin puncta was observed (Table 1). I used the term co-purify rather than enrichment to more strictly distinguish if a protein is just present in a biochemical fractionation versus if additional evidence is available to support that it is also spatially present or enriched in the SVs by microscopic methods.

These effects were blocked by adding a specific mGluR1 antagonist, but not with a specific mGluR5 antagonist.

12/6/2017 Pim
Inference of actin cytoskeleton term: "1) FILIP1 has been identified as an interactor of the actin-crosslinking protein Filamin A, see Fig 3 in PMID 12055638. In COS7 cells GFP-tagged FILIP1 shows a fibre-like distribution and co-localizes with phalloidin staining of filamentous actin (Fig 2 in PMID 12055638). Deletion of the Filamin-interaction portion of FILIP disrupts this distribution, indicating that FILIP1 can interact with the actin cytoskeleton via Filamin A. Given the similar distribution of FILIP1 and Filamin A in neurons, both enriched in spines, it is highly likely that also in neuronal spines, FILIP1 is bound to actin through Filamin A."

comments.species: from M&M: "Experiments were performed on adult (3–5 months old) male Sprague Dawley rats from Charles River (Raleigh, NC)."
comments.rationale: Using a validated antibody this paper describes that cortactin, a protein implicated in actin nucleation and branching, is expressed in hippocampal CA1 neurons and is enriched in dendritic spines. Here it concentrates in the core of the spine. Together with evidence that cortactin binds F-actin through its amino-terminal acidic region (see e.g. PMID 11018051) and that removal of this domain abrogates spine targeting (PMID 14684878), suggests that cortactin is enriched in spines by binding to F-actin.

comments.rationale: This paper demonstrates localization of drebrin A in dendritic spines in the cerebral cortex using confocal and electron microscopy (figures 3,4, 5). This paper also presents data that Drebrin A co-sediments with other actin-binding proteins in the insoluble fraction (figure 6). And, immuno-EM labeling on synaptosomes showed Drebrin A labeling on filamentous materials that were associated with postsynaptic densities (figure 7). Finally, biochemical evidence is provided that drebrin interacts with actin and the actin-binding proteins gelsolin and myosin II (figure 8).  Together these data indicate that Drebrin A is bound to the postsynaptic actin cytoskeleton.

comments.rationale:
MADD/DENN was shown to function as KIF1 motor adapter. GTP-bound Rab3, which is a marker of synaptic vesicle transport vesicles (STVs), binds MADD which then allows KIF1-dependent transport of Rab3-STVs. Expression of a dominant negative MADD  (death domain) blocks binding of Rab3-STVs to KIF1. Reduced Rab3-STVs in distal axons and a decrease in anterograde-moving Rab3-STVs in proximal axons were observed in neurons expressing dominant negative MADD/DENN or miRNA against MADD/DENN. Taken together, these results indicates that movement of STVs to presynaptic sites via KIF1 motors are dependent on MADD/DENN.

29/3/2017 Pim
- Rab3A is a known SV protein and in this paper and PMID:7539720 considered as a marker of precursor synaptic vesicles (see discussion with expert in feedback section). Effects on Rab3A lcoalization are therefore annotated against transport of synaptic vesicles.

comments.rationale:
It is shown that postsynaptic perfusion with PKM zeta (a constitutively active splice variant of the PRKCZ gene) increases postsynaptic AMPAR responses. This is inhibited by pep2m, a peptide that inhibits NSF/GluR2 interactions (Figure 1). The effect does not require exocytotic insertion of GluRs, since Botox B is unable to inhibit the effect (Figure 1D), and there is no increase in the surface or total level or GluR2 (Figure 3E). Using synaptosomes, it is shown that PKM-zeta dependent LTP does lead to a increase in synaptic GluR2 and GluR3, and that this is blocked by pep2m and a ZIP (a inhibitor with some specificity to PKM-zeta). It is thus concluded that PKM-zeta increases AMPAR responses by recruiting extrasynaptic GluRs to the PSD.

Ling et.al. 2006 demonstrates that PKM zeta-induced potentiation requires an increase in the number of receptors, not an increase in receptor conductance.

It should be noted that PKM-zeta has long been suspected to be essential for postsynaptic LTP, but that this is subject on an ongoing debate. (Tsokas et.al. 2016).

comments.rationale:
This publication provides some evidence that PKC lambda/iota regulates the insertion of AMPAR at the PSD.
-A specific shRNA blocks the induction of LTP in hippocampal slices, which can be rescued by re-expression of PKC-lambda. (Figure 1)
-PI3K activation increases PKC lambda auto-phosphorylation and EPSC amplitudes. This is inhibited by PKC-lambda shRNA, and an inhibitor (Myr-aPKC-PS, more commonly known as ZIP) with some specificity to PKC-lambda. (Figure 2).
-PI3K activation leads to increased surface expression of GluRs, which is inhibited by Myr-aPKC-PS (Figure 3C-F).
-PI3K activation leads to increased mEPSC amplitudes, which can be blocked by PKC-lambda shRNA and Myr-aPKC-PS (Figure 3G-H).

It should be noted that at the concentration used, Myr-aPKC-PS also strongly inhibits PKC-zeta (see Figure 1D and Tsokas et al 2016). Thus, in several assays in this publication, it cannot be excluded that observed effects are mediated by PKC-zeta. The role of PKC-lambda in LTP is debated and likely involves an interplay with PKC-zeta expression (Tsokas et al 2016).

comments.species: The authors employed hippocampal organotypic slice cultures from mice lacking Synaptobrevin-2 and also, other key presynaptic proteins, cryofixation, and three-dimensional electron tomography to study the mechanism of synaptic vesicle docking in the same experimental setting, with high precision, and in a near-native state.
comments.rationale:
Experiment explanation: The authors systematically characterized the molecular and morphological nature of the docked and primed SV states with nanometer accuracy by the used of high-pressure freezing (HPF), freeze substitution (FS), and electron tomography (ET) of mouse mutants synapses. Taking in account as analysis parameters: SV Diameter and  Number of SVs within a distance of: 100, 40, 0-5, 0-2nm of AZ. 

Protein Function: The analysis of Syb- 2 KO terminals revealed a severe reduction in the number of docked SVs and a prominent accumulation of SVs close (4–8 nm) to the AZ (Figure 4).However, Syb-2 KO synapses showed no changes in the number of SVs within 40 or 100 nm of the AZ. Based on these results, the authors concluded that Syb-2 is required for SV Docking. 

Protein Location: Confocal microscopy of WT slices showed a specific punctate labeling of Syb-2, which highly colocalized with VGLUT1 but was absent in Syb-2 KO cultures (data not shown).

comments.rationale:
Researchers found an enrichment of Crk-L in mouse adult and developing neuromuscular synapses by performing immunostaining using an antibody against Crk-L. Staining was found in synapses identified using alpha-Bungarotoxin-594 to label AChRs. Imaging was performed using confocal microscopy.

10/4/2017 Pim:
- "extrinsic component..." selected because the paper shows recruitment of Crk-L to the plasma membrane via interaction with another protein.

comments.species: Mice carrying floxed alleles of Crk and Crk-L have been described previously (Park et al. 2006; Park and Curran 2008). Mice that carry a myf5cre allele, which confers Cre recombinase expression in myoblasts and myotubes, have been described previously (Tallquist et al. 2000).
comments.rationale: Crk-L is a postsynaptic protein which plays a crucial role in NMJ synapse formation concomitantly with CrkI/II, by directly interacting with Dok-7.  Knockdown of both CrkI/II and Crk-L was necessary to induce a significant effect in postsynaptic AChR cluster formation, an effect that was partially rescued by overexpression of CrkL (Hallock et  al., 2015). Transgenic mice lacking CrkL and CrkI/II in myotubes show neonatal lethality and study of their embryonic neuromuscular synapses reveal a lower number of synapses which resulted in a low level of innervated myofibers, decreased synaptic size and decreased number of synaptic AChRs. Moreover, motor axons grow beyond AChR cluster. Overall, CrkL has a crucial role in neuromuscular pre- and postsynaptic differentiation and its absence can be compensated by CrkI/II.

comments.rationale:
Authors characterized synaptobrevin 1 (syb1, VAMP1) as a v-SNARE in SV exocytosis by a molecular rescue approach and found that this paralog of syb2 is expressed in a subset of hippocampal neurons in their syb2 KO culture (Fig 1). 

They could correlate the size of the RRP of individual neurons to their syb1 expression levels and showed that knocking down syb1 dramatically decreases the RRP of mass-cultured syb2 KO neurons (Fig 2).

Concluding that Synaptobrevin 1 mediates vesicle priming and evoked release in a subpopulation of hippocampal neurons.

Experiment: They grew murine hippocampal neurons from syb2 KO (Schoch et al. 2001) and WT littermates on glial microislands and performed whole cell patch-clamp experiments on autaptic neurons.

To date Calnexin is considered mainly as a single-pass type 1 membrane protein of the ER membrane (Wiest et al. 1995).

Fig.2B-D+4: human cells + mouse NPR-ECD protein

comments.rationale: Using electron microscopy it is shown that Piccolo/Aczonin is present at the active zone of conventional synapses (figure 1), and at the ribbon of photoreceptor ribbon synapses (figure 2). No knockout control is available, but the authors used multiple antibodies against Piccolo that essentially show the same staining pattern.

comments.species:
Adult (200 g) Sprague–Dawley rats were anaesthetised, and kept 2h at 4 °C before dissecting the brains. Vibratome sections (50 um thick) through the primary somatosensory cortex and the hippocampus were collected.

Antibody production: Female Biozzi BP2 mice were immunised by i.p. injection of 40 ug of the recombinant domain of TI-VAMP.
comments.rationale:
Using a newly produced monoclonal antibody to TI-VAMP that improves signal/noise immunodetection, authors reported that TI-VAMP is also present in subsets of axon terminals of the adult rat brain. 

Four distinctive populations of labelled axon terminals were identified. The presynaptic localisation of TI-VAMP in these locations was demonstrated by co-localisation with synaptophysin. 

1) The hippocampal mossy fibres of the dentate gyrus and of CA3 (Fig 3A-C). 
2) The striatal peridendritic terminal plexuses in the globus pallidus (GP), substantia nigra pars reticulata (SNr), 
3) peridendritic plexuses in the central nucleus of the amygdala
4) The primary sensory afferents in the dorsal horn of the spinal cord (Fig 5D-E). 

Subcellular localisation of TI-VAMP:
Authors carried out ultrastructural investigations, focussing on the hippocampal dendritic and axon terminal TI-VAMP labelled. The preparations were analysed with two types of pre-embedding procedures (immunogold and immunoperoxidase) on adult rat brain samples. In the hilus and in CA3,TI-VAMP labelling was distributed throughout the terminal bouton and, at their level of resolution, it decorated indiscriminately all the synaptic vesicles (Fig 6).

Finally author showed that TI-VAMP is not restricted to one neurotransmitter, TI-VAMP is present in both GABAergic and glutamatergic terminals (Fig 8)

comments.species:
Rat: Primary cultures of cerebellar neurons were prepared from the cerebella of 7-day-old Sprague Dawley rat pups of both sexes (Anggono et al., 2006). 

Mouse: Dissociated primary hippocampal neuronal cultures were prepared from E17.5 C56BL/6J mouse embryos of both sexes.

Cerebellar neurons were transfected between 5 and 7 days in culture, whereas hippocampal neurons were transfected between 6 and 8 days in culture with Lipofectamine 2000 (Gordon et al., 2011).

7/4/2017 PIm
- The over-expresssion of VAMP4 used in figure 7 is used as specificity control for the shRNA-mediated KD. Therefore, the species of this VAMP4 protein is not relevant and the annotation against rat VAMP4 is approved.
comments.rationale:
Activity-dependent bulk endocytosis (ADBE) is the dominant SV endocytosis mode under intense neuronal activity. 

The authors investigated whether directed sorting of SV cargo occurs at the plasma membrane during ADBE, since this will ultimately impact on the molecular composition of SVs generated via this endocytosis mode. 

They examined the retrieval of different SV cargo molecules during intense stimulation using a series of genetically encoded pH-sensitive reporters in neuronal cultures, and they found that only one was preferentially trafficked via ADBE-VAMP4. 

Author showed two important results:
1) VAMP4 is not simply represented as an ADBE cargo, actually authors showed by using biochemical fractionation experiments, that endogenous VAMP4 was selectively enriched on bulk endosomes.

2)  VAMP4 is essential for ADBE to proceed. Authors determined this by using validated shRNA oligonucleotides against VAMP4. When 40Hz/10s stimulation was applied, VAMP4 knockdown abolished TMR-dextran uptake, an inhibition fully rescued by expression of wild-type VAMP4- pHluorin (Figures 7B and C). Therefore, in addition to being the first identified ADBE cargo molecule, VAMP4 is essential for this key endocytosis mode.

VAMP4 Location: Figure 7A --> Representative images show nerve terminals labeled with VAMP4 antibodies after immunogold detection and silver enhancement. Almost all silver particles were localized to endosomal structures after 40 Hz stimulation (indicated by arrows).

comments.species: The studies were performed on brains of Wistar rats of either sex (Charles River).
comments.rationale:
This study uses two methods to describe the subcellular localization of RIM4gamma.

-Using subcellular fractionation based on synaptosomes, RIM4gamma was detected in a triton-insoluble fraction. This fraction is enriched in pre-and postsynaptic densities. (Figure 2A).
-In confocal microscopy, RIM4gamma was present in dendrites, with some overlap with the synaptic markers synapsin and PSD95 (figure 2C-E).

Neither experiment has sufficient resolution to discriminate between pre- and postsynaptic localization.

The antibody used was verified using RNA knockdown and western blot analysis (Figure 3A).

comments.species: The studies were performed on brains of Wistar rats of either sex (Charles River).
comments.rationale:
The authors use RNA knockdown for RIM3gamma in cultured neurons to study its role in synapse stability. RIM3 knockdown led to a pronounced reduction in the number of synapsin and PSD95 puncta per um dendrite. In addition, there was a strong reduction in the number of dendritic spines. This suggests that RIM3gamma plays are role in the formation or elimination of synapses.

It should be noted that the knockdown used had more widespread phenotype that include a strong defect in neuronal arborization (Figure 3). It is currently unclear whether the observed phenotype on synapse density is independent of the arborization effect.

The knockdown used was verified with a custom made antibody and western blot analysis (Figure 3A).

comments.species:
Double  immunofluorescence  labeling  of cultured rat hippocampal neurons (12 days in vitro) was carried out essentially as described (22) by using affinity-purified ERC1b antibodies  (p224)  and  monoclonal  antibodies  to  RIM1
 or synapsin, with secondary antibodies coupled with Alexa Fluor 488 and 546 (Molecular Probes). Immunoelectron microscopy of brain sections was performed by using a preembedding 1.4-nm immunogold  procedure  with  signal  amplification  with  the  HQ silver enhancement kit (Nanoprobes, Yaphank, NY) essentially as described (23).
comments.rationale:
This publication provides multiple lines of evidence that ELKS1 is localized to the presynaptic active zone.

-In subcellular fractionation assays from synaptosomes, ELKS1 was detected in an insoluble fraction highly enriched in active zone markers RIM and liprin (figure 4A).
-In confocal microscopy imaging, a large portion of ELKS signal overlapped with the presynaptic markers RIM and synapsin (figure 5A-B).
-Using immuno electron microscopy, ELKS was detected at active zones in hippocampal slices (figure 5C), and additional signal was detected throughout the nerve terminal observed .

Note that although the article refers to the antibody used for immunocytochemistry as ELKS1 specific, it recognizes both ELKS1 and ELKS2. Extensive characterization of the antibody, including knockout controls, is provided in Liu et.al. 2014 and Held et. al. 2016. ELKS1 and ELKS2 are both expressed at synapses in these cultures (Held et.al. 2016).

comments.species:
Double  immunofluorescence  labeling  of cultured rat hippocampal neurons (12 days in vitro) was carried out essentially as described (22) by using affinity-purified ERC1b antibodies  (p224)  and  monoclonal  antibodies  to  RIM1
 or synapsin, with secondary antibodies coupled with Alexa Fluor 488 and 546 (Molecular Probes). Immunoelectron microscopy of brain sections was performed by using a preembedding 1.4-nm immunogold  procedure  with  signal  amplification  with  the  HQ silver enhancement kit (Nanoprobes, Yaphank, NY) essentially as described (23).
comments.rationale:
This publication provides multiple lines of evidence that ELKS2 is localized to the presynaptic active zone.

-In subcellular fractionation assays from synaptosomes, ELKS2 was detected in an insoluble fraction highly enriched in active zone markers RIM and liprin (figure 4A).
-In confocal microscopy imaging, a large portion of ELKS signal overlapped with the presynaptic markers RIM and synapsin (figure 5A-B).
-Using immuno electron microscopy, ELKS was detected at active zones in hippocampal slices (figure 5C) and additional signal was present throughout the nerve terminal.

Note that although the article refers to the antibody used for immunocytochemistry as ELKS1 specific, it recognizes both ELKS1 and ELKS2. Extensive characterization of the antibody, including knockout controls, is provided in Liu et.al. 2014 and Held et. al. 2016. ELKS1 and ELKS2 are both expressed at synapses in these cultures (Held et.al. 2016). In addition, Ohtsuka et.al. found a very similar localization using a different antibody.

31/8/2017 Pim
The anitbody in this paper does not distinguish ELKS1 from ELKS2 but according to aggregated evidence the AZ annotation seemd more than justified. This rationale is:
- PMID:12391317: In hippocampal neurons ELKS1 AND/OR ELKS2 are located to the AZ
- PMID:27253063: In hippcampal neurons both ELKS1 and  ELKS2  are co-localized in individual synapses (note: 'presynapse' is beyond resolution here)
- PMID: 27253063/ticket #331: Both ELKS1 and  ELKS2 regulate a highly localized presynaptic process 'synaptic vesicle priming (GO:0016082)' a process that resides in the AZ (note: this may be rather circumstantial by itself, but strengthens microscopy-based observations)

comments.species: All experiments using mice were performed according to institutional guidelines at Harvard University. Conditional double knockout (cDKO) mice that remove the ELKS1α/2α proteins were generated by crossing conditional knockout mice for the Erc1 ([Liu et al., 2014] RRID:IMSR_JAX:015830) and Erc2 ([Kaeser et al., 2009] RRID:IMSR_JAX:015831) genes. ELKS1α/2α cDKO mice were maintained as double homozygote line.
comments.rationale:
Using an ELKS1/2 double knockout, this publication provides multiple lines of evidence that ELKS1 controls synaptic vesicle priming at excitatory synapses.

-ELKS DKO leads to a reduction in spontaneous and action potential-evoked release at excitatory synapses (Figure 2).
-ELKS DKO displays a reduction of sucrose-induced vesicle fusion, an established method for measuring vesicle priming. This effect can be rescued by reintroduction of ELKS1 (figure 7). In addition, there is a significant reduction in vesicle fusion during short action potential trains, which is in line with a defect in priming (figure 4).

13/4/2017 Pim
- Effect on priming may be synapse type related. In inhibitory synapses this effect seems absent although ELKS influences SV release via an indirect mechanism. (see ticket #333).

comments.species: Mice were generated according to standard procedures (Ho et al., 2006 and Kaeser et al., 2008), targeting exon 3 of the ELKS2 gene by homologous recombination in R1 ES cells.
comments.rationale:
Kaeser et.al. provides evidence that ELKS2 is involved in synaptic vesicle priming at inhibitory synapses.

-In hippocampal slices, there is an increase in action potential-evoked release at inhibitory synapses. There is a small effect on release probability (as measured by paired pulse), this is not sufficient to explain the effect on evoked release. This indirectly suggests an increase of the primed vesicle pool (Figure 4).
-More directly, in hippocampal cultures, there is an increase in vesicle priming (measured with sucrose application, figure 7). This preparation shows an similar increase in action-potential evoked release (figure 6). 

It should be noted that there is a complex interplay between ELKS1 and ELKS2 in vesicle priming, that is dependent on the type of synapses. In ELKS1/2 double knockouts, there is no effect on vesicle priming in inhibitory synapses (Liu et.al. 2014, Held et.al. 2016), but an decrease at excitatory synapses (Held et.al. 2016). The exact contribution of ELKS2 in vesicle priming has not been determined.

comments.species: Primary mouse hippocampal cultures from newborn pups were generated as previously described (Ho et al., 2006; Kaeser et al., 2008; Kaeser et al., 2009; Kaeser et al., 2011).
comments.rationale:
Liu et.al. provides multiple lines of evidence that ELKS proteins control action potential-evoked calcium influx in inhibitory presynaptic terminals.

-In presynaptic calcium imaging, ELKS DKO shows a reduction in AP-induced calcium entry (Figure 8).
-ELKS DKO displays a reduction in AP-induced vesicle fusion as measured with electrophysiology (Figure 5). Release has a reduced sensitivity to Ca2+ (EC50) without affecting the cooperativity. This is in line with a defect in calcium entry, and not the calcium sensor of the release machinery. 
-There is no defect in the synaptic localization of calcium channels, as shown with immunocytochemistry (figure 9). 
Taken together, these data show that ELKS proteins control the opening of calcium channels.

Since this study has been performed in ELKS1/2 double knockouts, the exact contribution of ELKS1 or ELKS2 is currently unknown.

12/4/2017 Pim
- These studies show that ELKS1 (in genetic interaction with ELKS2) regulate the activity of VGCC's in the presynapse.
13/4/2017 Pim
- Effect on SV release synapse type related. In inhibitory synapses (this annotation) ELKS influences SV release via an indirect mechanism, whereas in excitatory synapses ELKS regulates SV priming (see ticket #331).

comments.rationale:
Exposure of mossy fibre neurons to Wnt7-containing culture medium derived from cerebellar granule cells increases the density of VAMP2, synapsin 1 and Bassoon puncta along axons. This is supported by an increase in the number of recycling synaptic vesicle sites as identified using antibodies against synaptotagmin-1 or FM1-43 labelling.

Conversely, VAMP2 puncta and number of recycling synaptic vesicle sites were significantly decreased in Dvl1 mutant mice or when Wnt7b signalling was interrupted by treatment with the Wnt inhibitor Sfrp-1. Dvl1 mutant mice further showed a decrease in the amount of synapsin 1 accumulating at cerebellar glomerular rosettes.

comments.species:
Synaptic vesicle preparations (M&M):
Vesicles used for STED and in situ PLA were purified using a hybrid of existing protocols allowing increase purity of SV and described in detail elsewhere (Ahmed S, Holt M, Riedel D, Jahn R. (2013): Small-scale isolation of synaptic vesicles from mammalian brain. Nat Protoc. 8(5):998-1009).
In the figure legend of Fig. S1 as well as in the "tissue preparation for histology" text (M&M section )in the supplementary material, the authors indicate that adult mice were used. 

Please note that in this reference publication, the authors use also rat and human tissue samples for their experiments. However, I referred only to the figures showing results from mouse-derived biological material.
comments.rationale:
Vesicular aminergic-associated transporter (Slc10a4) is co-localized with synaptic vesicles positive for VAChT and VMAT2 as show by STED microscopy and in situ proximity ligation assay (Fig. 1 F-I). Immunoblotting of purified synaptic vesicles for VAChT, VMAT2 and VAAT confirm VAAT-localization to SVs (Fig. 4 C).
This observation is supported by co-localization analysis of Slc10a4 with VAChT and VMAT2 in mouse striatum and spinal cord, Fig. S1 H-I and S1 J-K, respectively. A biochemical support for these findings is shown in Fig. S1 O  (immunoisolation of transporter-positive vesicles followed by Western blot detection).
Additionally, association of the transporter with SVs at symmetrical synapses is assessed by immunogold labelling (electron microscopy, see Fig. S1 L). 

Immunohistochemistry experiments on adult mouse brain sections (Fig. S1 B-F) and on human brain samples (Fig. S1 G) confirm distribution of the protein in brain regions containing cholinergic, dopaminergic or serotonergic neurons. The data is supported by RNA in situ hybridization experiments detecting slc10a4 RNA in cholinergic and monoaminergic regions of mouse CNS (Fig 1A-E).

4/9/2017 Pim
- Based on the known transmembrane topology of the protein, the "integral component of ... membrane" term was chosen.

comments.species: Mutant mice were generated by homologous recombination experiments with R1 embryonic stem cells and genotyped as described in SI Materials and Methods.
comments.rationale:
This publication provides evidence that Piccolo is involved in presynaptic vesicle clustering. In neuronal cultures of Piccolo knockout mice, with additional knockdown of Bassoon, there is a reduction in the in the number of vesicles per synaptic bouton (Figure 4G-H). There also appears to be a reduction of the number of docked vesicles (Figure 4L, N), but it unclear whether this is a direct effect, or caused indirectly by a reduction in vesicle clustering. Knockout of Piccolo alone had no effect on vesicle clustering or docking, suggesting that Piccolo and Bassoon may be redundant in this.

The data presented in this paper should be considered with some caution. The genetic manipulation to delete Piccolo is a hypomorph, meaning that some Piccolo splice variants are still expressed (Waites et.al. 2011). In addition, due to the very large size of Piccolo, available techniques make it difficult to accurately measure Piccolo levels in cell lysates. Waites et.al. also shows that Piccolo regulates the assembly of presynaptic F-actin, which is in line with phenotype in vesicle clustering.

comments.rationale:
Using both confocal microscopy and superresolution STED microscopy, is demonstrated that DSyd-1 is present at the presynaptic active zone of the drosophila neuromuscular junction.

DSyd-1 closely colocalized with BRP a well established marker of the active zone (Figure 2D, 3). Dsyd-1 staining was reminiscent of the staining pattern of DLiprin, another constituent of the active zone (Figure 3). 

A knockout control is provided for the DSyd-1 antibody.

The mammalian gene mSYD1A might also be present at synapses (Wentzel 2013) but currently available data are not sufficient to prove this.

28/3/2017 Pim
The referenced figures  show an effect on synapse density. The authors state that CTTNBP2 afects both formation of new synapses and the maintenance of exisiting ones:
1. "Therefore, the experiments performed during DIV 12–18 favor a role of CTTNBP2 in **spinogenesis**"
2. "These data suggest that CTTNBP2 is likely also involved in the **maintenance of dendritic spines**"

The approporiate terms for these processed would be: 
ad 1: 'regulation of synapse assembly (GO:0051963)' 
ad 2: 'maintenance of synapse structure (term not in SynGO)'

One can also use a single more general term to capture both phenomena: 'regulation of synapse organization (GO:0050807)'

comments.rationale:
Fig 1, 2. Used atomic force microscopy (AFM) on the calyx-type nerve terminal of the chick ciliary ganglion to localize single calcium channels. Calcium channels were tagged using a biotylinated form of the Cav2.2 specific venom peptide omega-conotoxin GVIA (b-omega-CTx). The labelled channels were visualized using avidin-coated 30nm gold particles. Controls used: untreated, b-omega-CTx treated without gold, and preblocking with untagged omega-CTx.

Nerve terminals were identified in vitro from structural clues together with staining using the vital dye 4-Di-2-Asp The location of the terminals was noted by their relation to an electron microscopy grid attached to the underside of the coverslip. A sketch was also made of the terminal and the surrounding cells and cell debris so that the calyx could be re-identified under the AFM.

comments.species:
The brains of adult male Sprague-Dawley rats (2 months old) were fixed and cut into coronal sections with a vibrating microtome.  
Mutant mice with targeted inactivation of Cav1.2 expression in the hippocampus (Cav1.2HCKO) were used in antibody verification.
comments.rationale:
Developed an antibody against the pore forming region of Cav1.2 that was used in light and electron microscopy of fixed and stained rat brain sections. 

Immunoperoxidase labeling for the Cav1.2 antibody was clustered in patches in the cytoplasm of dendritic shafts and along the plasma membrane of dendrites (Fig. 3A–F). Labeled dendrites often formed synaptic contacts with unlabeled axon terminals, and most of these synapses were asymmetric (Fig. 3A,D,E). Cav1.2 was observed less frequently in dendritic spines where the peroxidase reaction product was observed mostly in the cytoplasm or regions of the plasma membrane away from the postsynaptic density (Fig. 4A–D).

The pre-embedding immunogold method was used to localize Cav1.2 more discretely. Immunogold particles were mostly localized in the cytoplasm of dendrites but a signiﬁcant portion of the labeling was also associated with the plasma membrane (Fig.7A,B), particularly in small dendrites. In dendritic spines of CA1 and CA3 neurons immunogoldparticles were predominantly intracellular (Table 2).

comments.rationale:
Serial section analysis of electron microscopic images from the hippocampal CA1 showed Cav2.3 to be predominantly presynaptic in the interpeduncular nucleus but mainly expressed postsynaptically in other brain regions. Cav2.3 immunogold particles were observed primarily in the extrasynaptic plasma membrane and occasionally over the presynaptic active zone. 

The following characteristics were used to identify presynaptic terminals: synaptic vesicle accumulation, presence of presynaptic specializations, and rigid alignment of presynaptic membrane to its postsynaptic partner. Synapses were identified based on postsynaptic thickening and electron dense materials in the synaptic cleft.

comments.rationale: Used antibodies to CaV3.2 to examine the localization of CaV3 in wild-type entorhinal cortex. The antibody to Cav3 was visualized by a silver-intensified immunogold reaction. CaV3.2 immunogold particles were present on asymmetrical synaptic terminals (Fig. 6a) in sections obtained from three wild-type mice. No CaV3.2 signal was identified on sections obtained from three CaV3.2−/− mice under either electron (Fig. 6a) or light microscopy (Supplementary Fig. 9).

comments.species: The quadruple homozygote floxed mice for RIM1αβ, RIM2αβγ, ELKS1α, and ELKS2α were generated by crossing single conditional knockout mice (Kaeser et al., 2008; Kaeser et al., 2009; Kaeser et al., 2011 ;  Liu et al., 2014).
comments.rationale:
It is demonstrated that RIM1 is required to maintain the structural integrity of the active zone. Genetic removal of active zone proteins RIM1, RIM2, ELKS1 and ELKS2 leads to a loss of Bassoon, Munc13 and Piccolo, and a reduction of RIMBP2 and Cav2.1 (Figure 1), thus showing a severe reduction of the active zone.

In line with disruption of the active zone, multiple essential functions of the presynaptic terminal are affected, including vesicle docking (figure 2), vesicle priming (figure 7), spontaneous and action potential induced fusion (figure 3 and 5) and calcium influx (figure 4).

Removal of RIM1/2 or ELKS1/2 alone is not sufficient to disrupt the active zone (figure 7).

10/4/2017 Pim

"Primary hippocampal neuron cultures were prepared from P0 Sprague-Dawley rat pups as described previously with minor changes."

14/6/2017 Pim
- At some point in Fig.7 the authors state "To determine whether AKAP150 binding specifically to calcineurin is required for NMDAR-triggered AMPAR endocytosis, we examined the effects of expressing a form of **mouse** AKAP150 in which the sequence that has been reported to be essential for binding calcineurin (amino acids 613–655) is deleted" (emphasis added). So, part of the evidence is made with a mouse speceis protein. This info is disregarded for this annotation.
comments.rationale:
Authors show in dissociated hippocampal cultures that AKAP150 plays a crucial role in mediating NMDA-induced AMPA receptor endocytosis. Interaction of AKAP150 and PSD95 is crucial for mediating this process, as a point mutation in PSD95 that prevents binding to AKAP150 is sufficient to prevent the endocytosis of AMPA triggered by NMDA treatment. Moreover, over expression of AKAP150 lacking the binding region to calcineurin, a protein known to be involved in NMDAR-dependent LTD and AMPA receptor endocytosis, also completely prevents the AMPA receptor endocytosis. These results suggest that AKAP150 plays a crucial role in the process by positioning calcineurin in the vicinity of NMDAR by interacting with PSD95.

14.6.2017 Pim
- The postulated role of AKAP150 in AMPAR-endocytosis is "Our results suggest that PSD-95's interaction with AKAP150 is critical for NMDAR-triggered AMPAR endocytosis and LTD, possibly because these scaffolds position calcineurin in the appropriate subsynaptic domain." Since AKAP150 is presented as a critical trigger I propose to check the "regulation of...." box.

Krox20 Cre/+;Actb LoxP/LoxP mice were created, which knocked out Actin, Beta in the Calyx of Held.  200 uM parasaggital brain stem slices were cut for capacitance recordings.  Actb LoxP/LoxP were used as controls.    

Mouse hippocampal cultures were prepared using Actb LoxP/LoxP mice.  Mice were transfected with a Cre-mCherry plasmid to create knockout.

8/6/2017
The species of the over-expression construct (Fig.7) is not relevant for species selection since serving as control for specificity of loss of native mouse protein.
comments.rationale:
Whole cell patch recordings of P7-P10 calyxes at 22-24 oC were given a 20 ms depolarization from -80 mV to +10 mV.   The initial rate of decay of the capacitance change was significantly slower (~33% of control) in the Actin, beta KO suggesting a slower rate of endocytosis following vesicle fusion (Fig 2. A-C).    Similar results were observed when the stimulus was changed to a 20 action potential equivalent stimulus (Fig. 2 D-F), performed at 34-37 oC (Fig. 2 G) and in older mice (P13-P14) (Fig. 2 H).

Hippocampal neurons were cultured from the Actb LoxP/LoxP mice transfected with Synaptophysin-pHluorin2X (SypH) with or without a Cre containing plasmid (Fig. 6 A and D).  SypH can be used to study vesicle recycling as it is non-fluorescent in relatively low pH environment of vesicles but is fluorescent in the higher pH extracellular environment.  Upon stimulation the decay of fluorescence was significantly slower than the control (Fig. 6 E-G).  This fluorescence was quenchable by a low pH solution applied externally indicating it was not a deficit in vesicle reacidification, but instead suggesting that the vesicles had not been endocytosed (Fig. 6H).  This effect was rescued by transfecting Actb in the KO cultures (Fig 7 A,B) but was not rescued by a version of Actb that could not polymerize (Fig 7 E,F).  Taken together this data suggests that Actin, beta is important for endocytosis.      

.

This paper is a review paper that integrates data from mouse and rat studies. I have agreed with annotating against the mouse protein because of KO data mentioned in the review.
comments.rationale: The paper summarizes the evidence from many original reports. It describes all the interaction partners known so far and describes the function and the role in organizing the synaptic vesicle recycling and the localization of the Ca-channels and in regulating Actin-dynamics and endocytosis as well as its role in regulating synaptic maintenance and integrity.

comments.species: Neurons were dissociated from various mouse cortex
comments.rationale:
This manuscript describes analysis of synaptic transmission in cortical neuronal autaptic cultures where a point mutation in a Cav2.1 (S218L) has been introduced by knock-in. The mutation is disease-related in humans and is strongly associated with migraine. This analysis shows that neurons in which harbor Cav2,1 with the S218L mutation clearly change presynaptic function. Neurons harboring this mutation show a greater susceptibility to block by the Cav2.1 blocker agatoxin, an increase in release probability and a shift in the Ca-dependence of of release to lower values. 
These changes were only seen in excitatory neurons, not inhibitory.

This effect is due in part to decreased levels of p35 (Experiment: Western blots of whole cell lysates show that rem4A expression decreased p35 levels (Fig 3A). Location: Immunolabeling for endogenous p35 shows that p35 is localized to vesicle release sites. p35 colocalized with vGlut labeled clusters along dendrites (Fig 3E), but also with vGlut clusters at nonsynaptic hot spots in axons having no nearby dendrites (Fig. 3F).

comments.species: Co-staining of endogenous LRRK2 (green) and PKARIIβ (red) in cultured mouse hippocampal neurons at 15 DIV. The middle two panels show the boxed areas in the top panel. The bottom panel shows LRRK2 (green) and PKARIIβ (red) staining in 15 DIV Lrrk2−/− hippocampal neurons (arrowheads point to dendritic spines). Scale bars represent 20 μm (top) and 5 μm (bottom).
comments.rationale:
Confocal microscopy experiments described in this article provide evidence that PKA RIIB is present at the postsynapse. Images suggest that RIIB is localized to dendritic spines, but the resolution is not sufficient to make that claim. A knockout control for the antibody is not provided.

comments.species:
Transgenic Mice
To reduce PKA activity selectively within the hippocampus and other forebrain regions, we have used the CaMKIIα promoter to express R(AB), an inhibitory form of the RIα subunit of PKA. After purification by CsC1 gradient centrifugation, the CaMKII-R(AB) transgene was purified away from vector sequences by digesting with BssHII. The 11.5 kb transgene was isolated by agarose gel electrophoresis and purified after electroelution using Elutip. Transgenic mice were generated by injecting the purified CaMKII-R(AB) transgene into pronuclei of BL6CBAF2/J zygotes ( Hogan et al. 1994). Founders were backcrossed to C57BL/6J mice. In some cases, because of breeding difficulties, mice from the R(AB)-2 transgenic line were crossed to B6CBAF1/J animals. Mice were maintained and bred under standard conditions, consistent with NIH guidelines and approved by the IACUC. For genotyping, tail DNA was prepared ( Laird et al. 1991) and analyzed by Southern blotting (Sambrook et al. 1989) using a transgene-specific probe.
comments.rationale:
The authors use a transgenic mouse line that overexpresses a dominant negative form of PKA RI alpha to study the role of PKA in long-term plasticity (LTP) at the Schaffer collaterals of the hippocampus. It is found that the late phase of LTP (L-LTP) is abolished in this mouse line, strongly suggesting that PKA is required for L-LTP.

It is well established that LTP at Schaffer collaterals is a postsynaptic process, requiring the recruitment of AMPA receptors. The exact mechanism of action for PKAs is not understood, but requires the phosphorylation of AMPA receptors (Man et. al). PKA RIB is also involved in LTD (Brandon et.al. 1995), a process that regulates synaptic transmission through endocytosis of receptors.

comments.species:
Generation of Mutant Mice.
The targeting of embryonic stem cells and the establishment of chimeras carrying the RIP3 mutation have been described(18). Three of the four REK2-derived cell lines and one of the four D3-derived cell lines that produced fertile chimeras contributed to the germline.Mouse genotypes were determined by Southern blot.
comments.rationale:
A knockout mouse line for PKA R1 beta is used to study its role in synaptic plasticity. It is shown that long term depression (LTD) at the schaffer collaterals is severely reduced in this mouse line. This demonstrates a role for R1 beta in LTD.

LTD is a postsynaptic process, requiring the endocytosis of AMPA receptors (Beattie et. al.). The exact mechanisms by which PKAs act in LTD is not understood, but requires phosphorylation of GluR1 (Man et.al.).

comments.species:
Generation of knock-out and wild-type mice The initial generation of RIIb-/- and AC1/AC8-/-
mice has been described previously (Brandon et al., 1998; Wong et al., 1999). Here, to
control for modifiers, mutants were subsequently back-crossed seven or
more times into either 129 (129S1/SvImJ; Jackson Laboratories, Bar Har-
bor, ME) or B6 (C57BL/6; Taconic Farms Inc., Germantown, NY) lines
for study.
comments.rationale:
The authors use a PKA RII beta knockout mouse to study its role in synaptic plasticity in the visual cortex. It is shown that long term depression (LTD) is abolished in layer V of the visual cortex. 

LTD is a postsynaptic process that requires the endocytosis of AMPA receptors (Beattie et al.,Kirkwood and Bear). In the hippocampus, PKA-mediated phosphorylation of GluR1 is required for AMPA trafficking. It has not formally been shown if this is also true in LTD in the visual cortex.

comments.species: Our S‐synaptosome preparation was adapted from two previously published protocols (Hebb & Whittaker, 1958; Huttner et al, 1983). Briefly, forebrains of one or two mice were homogenized in 4 ml of ice‐cold homogenization buffer (0.32 M Sucrose, 4 mM HEPES pH 7.4, 1 μM PMSF, 1 μg/ml Aprotinin, 1 μg/ml Leupeptin) using a 5‐ml glass‐Teflon homogenizer with 12 gentle strokes.
comments.rationale: The authors used synaptosomes derived from vGlut-Venus knockin mice to enrich for glutamatergic presynaptic terminals. Mass spectrometry was performed to detect protein content, which identified PKA RI alpha. Although this method favors the detection of presynaptic proteins, postsynaptic or extrasynaptic localization of RI alpha cannot be excluded with this method.

comments.rationale:

Fig. 4: colocalization of EPHA7 with postsynaptic AChR but not with presynatic SV2 at the NMJ.

25/4/2017 Pim
- The authors discuss distinguising presynaptic, postsynaptic and Swann cell localization of EPHA7:
"It is possible that the receptors localized at NMJ are
present on the presynaptic terminal of motor neurons
rather than the postsynaptic apparatus on muscle fiber.
To confirm the concentration of EphA4, EphA7, and
ephrin-A2 on the postsynaptic specializations, immunostaining
was performed on denervated muscle. Upon
denervation, the axon terminal normally degenerates
by day 4 after nerve cut. However, staining by antibody
against EphA4, EphA7, or ephrin-A2 remained at the
NMJ twenty days after denervation (Figs. 4A–4C). In
contrast, antibody against the presynaptic protein synapsin
I stained intensely at the adult NMJ but the staining
disappeared at day 4 after denervation (Fig. 4D).
Although both the ligands and receptors remained at
the NMJ after nerve injury, the intensity of staining at
the synapses reduced considerably. This expression
profile is similar to that observed for the localization of
some other postsynaptic proteins, such as the muscle
specific kinase (MuSK) and neuregulin (NRG), in denervated
muscle (Bowen et al., 1998; Rimer et al., 1998)." ... "To further confirm the concentration of Eph receptors
on the postsynaptic side of NMJ, the localization of
EphA7 was compared with that of SV2, which is concentrated
in the presynaptic terminals of motor neurons.
Much of the EphA7 staining did not overlap with
the SV2 staining, indicating that the localization of
EphA7 was distinct from that of SV2 (Fig. 4E). Taken
together, our data strongly suggests that there is localization
of EphA4, EphA7, and ephrin-A2 at the postsynaptic
apparatus."
- Eph7A has a TM domain. Authors conclude "Importantly, both receptors, as well as the
ligand ephrin-A2, are concentrated at the postsynaptic
membrane on muscle fiber." we could make a "integral component of postsynaptic membrane" for this.

17/5/2017 Pim
- The postsynaptic nAChRs are a marker for the "postsynaptic specialization membrane". Therefore this term was selected over "postsynaptic membrane" localization of EPHA7.

comments.species: M&M: "Primary cultured neurons from SCR-KO **mice** were prepared with P1– P3 mice".
comments.rationale: Fbxl20/SCRAPPER is enriched in synaptic membrane fractions from mouse brain (Figure 1D). Immunofluorescence analysis revealed a punctate distribution of SCRAPPER (Figure 1F) that predominantly colocalized with synaptophysin, a known synaptic vesicle protein and presynapse marker. Fbxl20 ubiquitinates and degrades the active zone protein Rim-1. Fbxl20 null mutant hippocampal neurons show increased spontaneous (mEPSC) frequency but not amplitude. The increased mEPSC frequency can be rescued to wild type levels by shRNA-mediated depletion of RIM-1. In hippocampal slices from Fbxl20 null mutant mice increased mini frequency can be rescued by blocking proteasome activity. Hence Fbxl20 modulates synaptic transmission by ubiquitination and degradation of Rim-1.

Fig 6F,G: The frequency of mEPSC was significantly increased in SCR-KO CA1 neurons in hippocampal slice preparations . mEPSC amplitude was not affected suggesting presynaptic role.
Fig 6B,C: Fbxl20/SCRAPPER Tunes Synaptic Transmission via Regulation of RIM: RIM KD in SCR-KO restores mEPSC frequency to WT levels.

comments.rationale:
Serial section analysis of electron microscopic (EM) images in the hippocampus, neocortex, striatum, and amygdala showed that Cav2.3 is preferentially localized postsynaptically in dendritic shafts and spines and, to a lesser extent, in presynaptic compartments. Particles were seen to be diffusely distributed along the plasma membrane of dendrites and the spines without any preference for specialized membrane compartments.

Quantitative counting of membrane bound immunoparticles in sections taken from the proximal part of the stratum radiatum (PSR) of CA1 found that 78.2% of particles were in postsynaptic compartments (dendritic shafts and spines) compared to 21.8% in presynaptic compartments. Postsynaptically, 47.7% of the observed particles were in dendritic shafts and 30.5% in the spines 

Cav2.3 knock-out (KO) mice were used to validate the specificity of immunolabeling.

comments.species: Transverse hippocampal slices were obtained from 3- to 4-week old Sprague-Dawley rats
comments.rationale:
Transverse hippocampal slices (400 micromolar) were submerged and continuously superfused with Krebs. Synaptic transmission was elicited and field EPSPs (excitatory post synaptic potentials) were recorded with 1- to 3-Mohm
pipettes filled with 3 M NaCI.  

Synaptic strength was monitored as maximal slope of the field EPSP recorded in hippocampal area CA1 during 0.033-Hz stimulation of the Schaffer collateral and commisural pathways.

Figs 1A, B show the contribution of Cav2.2 (N-type) to synaptic vesicle exocytosis by demonstrating that a specific blocker of N-type channels (omega-Conotoxin-GVIA)  causes a rapid (but incomplete) depression of synaptic transmission.

comments.rationale:
Agrin is concentrated in the synaptic cleft of ribbon (Fig. 4) and conventional (Fig. 5) synapses of the inner and outer plexiform layers. As the majority of synapses in plexiform layers are labeled and many of these synapses are glutamatergic (PMID: 7902364) we assume that excitatory glutamateric synapses contain Agrin in the synaptic cleft.

12/6/2017 Pim

We believe that the evidence for our annotation is very strong." Therefore, ECM part of the term is derived from knowledge on the canonical function of the protein.This notion agreed with annotations present in the Uniprot database.

comments.species:
Here we present a large-scale proteomic analysis of the
postsynaptic proteome (PSP) of mouse brain. p.17
comments.rationale:
Supplemental table S1 contains 698 synaptic proteins identified in three different experimental approaches: isolated PSD preparation, MAGUK-associated signalling complexes (MASC) and AMPA receptor complexes (ARCs).
AGRIN_MOUSE was found in the isolated PSD fraction.

Note: For proteins coming from datasets derived from PSD (detergent-resistant synaptic junctions) preparations without defined selection / enrichment of the pre- or postsynaptic compartment we cannot assign these proteins to excitatory and/or inhibitory nor to the presynapse or / and postsynapse without further information. Furthermore such preparations contain also ECM components as well as components of tightly associated astrocytic endfeet.

comments.rationale:
Fig.5
Pre-embedding immunoelectron microscopy using an anti-CAPS-1 antibody. 

The antibody (polyclonal antibody directed against rat CAPS1 was generated with GST-rCAPS1 (218–390) fusion protein as the antigen and affinity purified). The specificity of the antibody was tested by Western Blot using CAPS-1 KO brain homogenate in a later study. Specificity of the antibody for immunolabelling was not tested.

Fig.4
Rat cortex subcellular fractions were analyzed by Western blotting using specific anti-CAPS-1 antibodies. CAPS-1 is a soluble protein that localizes to a large soluble synaptic pool in LS2 (cytosolic synaptosomal fraction) and a small membrane bound pool associated with the vesicle fraction LP2 (crude synaptic vesicle fraction).

Antibody information from the M&M: Recombinant GST-rCAPS1 (218–390) fusion protein was generated by using the expression plasmid pGEX-rCAPS1 (218–390), which encodes rat CAPS1 residues 218–390 in frame with GST (18). A polyclonal antibody directed against rat CAPS1 was generated with GST-rCAPS1 (218–390) fusion protein as the antigen. The antiserum was affinity-purified on GST-rCAPS1 (218–390) and immobilized on an Immobilon-P polyvinylidene fluoride membrane (Millipore) (19). The antibody was mono-specific for CAPS1 and cross-reacted with the murine orthologue, as demonstrated by Western blots with wild-type and CAPS1-deficient brain tissue from a deletion mutant mouse.

comments.rationale: Upon ARF6 knockdown, synaptic vesicles are depleted and endosome-like cisternae accumulate (Fig1). This can be reverted by expressing shRNA resistant ARF6 (Fig S3) or phenocopied by acute chemical ARF6GEF inhibition by SecinH3 (Fig 3), indication that this is really attributed to impaired AFR6 function. Blocking synaptic activity by TTX also reverts the synaptic vesicle and cisternae number, showing that synaptic activity is needed for the ARF6-dependent SV pool maintenance (Fig4). ARF6 could regulate SV endocytosis and recycling either directly at the plasma membrane and/or from the endosome-like cisternae.

"We found that 32.1 ± 5.4% of S-SCAM clusters were apposed to VGAT clusters, whereas 69.8 ± 5.8% of VGAT clusters were apposed to S-SCAM clusters. We also immunostained cells with anti-gephyrin antibody (Fig. 1b, lower panel). We found that 35.4 ± 7.4% of S-SCAM clusters were co-localized with gephyrin clusters, whereas 62.7 ± 10.9% of gephyrin clusters were co-localized with S-SCAM clusters. These findings suggest that almost one-third of signals detected by anti-S-SCAM antibody arelocalized at inhibitory synapses."

Literal

- Fig.1 shows that MAGI2 is localized at inh. synapses.
- Fig.8a shows direct interaction of the cytosolic MAGI2 protein with transmembrane neurologin 2.
- Fig.8e shows colocalization of MAGI2 and neuroligin 2 in inhibitory synapses.
Neuroligin is a known postsynapic protein of inhibitory synapses that interacts with presynaptic neurexin proteins. 
In conclusion, via PPI and colocalization with neuroligin 2 a postsynaptic localization of MAGI2 is evidenced. Since MAGI2 interacts with the TM neuroligin protein the membrane association type is "extrinsic component...."

- Fig.2/3 shows localization of genetically encoded EGFP attached to native mouse Munc13 paralogs. Strong colocalization with the presynaptic markers VGlut1 and Bassoon together with a lack of staining of the postsynaptic MNTB cell body strongly support a presynaptic localization.

Figure 1 shows expression of Munc13-1 in mouse calyx of Held synapses. As a negative control for the antibody staining calyces from Munc13-1 KO mice were used. The mice have been described previously (Augustin et al., 2001; Varoqueaux et al., 2002). 
Fig.2 and Fig.3 show localization of genetically encoded EGFP attached to native mouse Munc13 paralogs. Munc13–XFP mice have been described previously (Kalla et al., 2006; Cooper et al., 2012).
comments.rationale:
Localization of Munc13 isoforms at the calyx of Held synapse.
- Fig.1 shows localization of native protein with subtype-specific antibodies. Strong colocalization with the presynaptic marker VGlut1 together with a lack of staining of the postsynaptic MNTB cell body strongly support a presynaptic localization. 
- Fig.2/3 shows localization of genetically encoded EGFP attached to native mouse Munc13 paralogs. Strong colocalization with the presynaptic markers VGlut1 and Bassoon together with a lack of staining of the postsynaptic MNTB cell body strongly support a presynaptic localization.
Table 1 presents a quantification of Munc13-1 staining intensity at Bassoon-immunoreactive active zones, demonstrating a high degree of localization to the presynaptic active zone.

comments.rationale:
CAPS associates with synaptic DCVs.

Fig.4
Immunogold labelling of lysed synapsosomes.The CAPS polyclonal antibodies used were generated either against a baculovirus-encoded rat CAPS protein (Ann et al. 1997) or against E. coli-expressed Drosophila CAPS fusion proteins (B. Berwin, unpublished data) and were affinity purified by the method of Olmsted 1981. Control studies conducted by immunofluorescence demonstrated that immunostaining was reduced to background in the presence of an E. coli-produced recombinant CAPS protein (J. Wassenberg, personal communication). In the immunogold procedure, gold-conjugated secondary reagents were used at a dilution where no labeling was observed in the absence of primary antibody.

Fig.5
DCV and synaptic vesicle (SV) fractions from rat brain homogenates were prepared and tested by Western Blot using CAPS polyclonal antibodies (no KO control). 
Fig 5A demonstrates an enrichment of CAPS in the LDCV pool in comparison to the SV pool.
Fig 5B and C: CAPS cosediments with DCVs, but not SVs using a sucrose gradient.
Fig. 5D: Treatment of DCV fraction with proteases cleaves VAMP2 and CAPS, but not a DCV content marker, indicating that CAPS is an extrinsic component of neuronal DCVs.

CAPS1/CAPS2-deficient (DKO) mice (Jockusch et al., 2007) from days e18 and e19...
comments.rationale:
The splice variant CAPS2b can fully rescue deficits in synaptic transmission (evoked release, readiliy-releasable pool) in isolated, autaptic CAPS-1/2 double KO neurons. 

Moreover, the data indicates that the priming function of CAPS2 lies in the N-terminal part of the protein (Splice variant CAPS2e, lacking the C-terminal MUN domain) can still (at least partially) rescue deficits in the readily-releasable pool size.

comments.species:
Mouse knock-out model; Deletion mutations in the mouse gene for Munc13-1 were
generated by homologous recombination in embryonic stem cells.
comments.rationale:
First description of the Munc13-1 knock out mouse using electrophysiology in autistic mouse hippocampal and stratal neurons.

Figure 1 shows a 90% reduction in glutamatergic synaptic transmission. GABAergic transmission id not impaired.

Figure 2 shows that the impaired glutamatergic neurotransmission results from a decrease in the size of the readily releasable vesicle pool, assessed by sucrose application.

comments.species: hippocampal slices were. prepared from littermate wild-type (WT) and Munc13-2–/– (KO) mice, aged between postnatal days P 18-35. The mice were previously described (Varoqueaux et al., 2002).
comments.rationale:
Extracellular field recordings in hippocampal slices from Munc13-2 KO mice.

Figure 1 shows an impaired input-output curves indicating impaired synaptic transmission at mossy fiber synapses in the absence of Munc13-2. Synaptic transmission at the Schaffer-collateral synapses recorded in stratum radiatum of area CA1 is not impaired.
Figure 2 shows that the loss of Munc13-2 leads to increased failures in mossy fiber synaptic transmission.
Figure 3 shows increased short-term synaptic plasticity in Munc13-2 KO mossy fiber synapses.
Figure 6 shows that the loss of Munc13-2 leads to a reduction in release probability at mossy fiber synapses.

using western blotting to identify the expression of VGLUT1.

A clear signal for VGLUT1 was observed in the total crude vesicular fraction (lane T), indicating that a subset of SVs in the fraction is expressing VGLUT1. As an indirect control for antibody specificity, a subset of the SVs that were immunoisolated for VGLUT2 do not show a VGLUT1 WB signal.

comments.species: Immunoblotting analysis of subcellular fractions from rat brain.
comments.rationale:
Immunoblotting analysis of subcellular fractions from rat brain with antibodies to SCAMPs 1 and 5, and to the NMDA receptor as control. 

The sub fractionation allows to enrich crude synaptic vesicles (LP2 fraction), and from these, a highly purified synaptic vesicles fraction (SV fraction) can be obtained. Figure 6 demonstrates a massive enrichment of SCAMP1 in both the LP2 and SV samples, suggesting that the protein is localized to synaptic vesicles.

Figure 7 demonstrates a massive enrichment of SCAMP5 in both the LP2 and SV samples, suggesting that the protein is localized to synaptic vesicles.

comments.species: CPX I and CPX II mutant mice were generated...
comments.rationale:
Single, autaptic hippocampal Complexin-1 and -2 double knock-out (DKO) neurons exhibit a decrease in evoked release (EPSC amplitude; Fig. 2A, B; Table 1), but not in the readily-relasable pool size (sucrose response; Fig 2D, E; Table 1). 

Complexin-1 and -2 can compensate for the loss of the respective other isoform in hippocampal autaptic neurons: Complexin-1 KO mice and Complexin-2 KO mice are viable and exhibit no deficits in evoked release (Fig 2B), whereas Complexin-1/2 DKO mice die a few hours after birth.

Complexin only regulates synaptic vesicle fusion, since the deficit in synaptic transmission can be rescued by elevating the extracellular calcium concentration (Fig. 5).
