comments.species: Figure 1 Expression and localization of profilin1 and profilin2 in mouse brain.
comments.rationale: Fig1C: quantitative immuno-EM for endogenous Profilin2. The pfn2 KO mouse was used as control. Quantification shows that profilin 2 is predominantly localised to the postsynaptic spine, with also significant labelling in presynaptic boutons and dendritic spines compared to background labelling in the pfn2 null mice.

comments.species: The higher mEPSC frequency was not due to an increased number of synapses in the striatum of pfn2 /  mice....Under resting conditions, no difference was seen in F/G-actin ratios in pfn2 /  mice and control littermates (Figure 7C). [page 2997]
comments.rationale: Spontaneous fusion frequency is increased in slices (Fig 6D) while the amplitude of the spontaneous responses (Fig 6A) and number of synapses (Fig 6B) remain the same in the pfn2 null mutant. Increasing the extracellular calcium also produced a bigger EPSC amplitude in pfn2 KO mice (Fig6E). These data show that the vesicular release probability is increased in absence of Profilin2. This could be related to altered presynaptic actin dynamics since depolarisation-induced actin polymerisation is synaptosomes from pfn2 null mice was impaired (Fig 7C) and no direct effects on proteins level of the release machinary itself were detected (Fig 7B).

comments.species:
GENERATION OF VGLUT1VENUS KI MICE.
The targeting vector was constructed on the basis of a 14 kb genomic clone of the VGLUT1 locus in pBluescript, which had been isolated from a λFIXII genomic library of the SV129 mouse strain (Stratagene). In the targeting vector, the STOP codon in the last coding exon (exon 12) of the VGLUT1 gene was replaced in-frame by a venus-loxP-neor-loxP cassette using recombineering techniques with engineered primers. The Venus cDNA was kindly provided by Dr. A. Miyawaki (RIKEN, Wako, Japan), and the recombineering toolbox was provided by Dr. N. Copeland (NCI, Frederick, MD). The venus-loxP-neor-loxP cassette was inserted between a 6.7 kb genomic sequence in 5′ position and a 7.9 kb genomic sequence in 3′ position (Fig. 1C). Mice carrying the mutated VGLUT1VenusNeo gene (VGLUT1vn/+) were generated by homologous recombination in embryonic stem cells (SV129/ola) as described previously (Thomas and Capecchi, 1987; Augustin et al., 1999) and identified by Southern blotting or PCR (Fig. 1D,E). To eliminate deleterious effects of the neomycin resistance gene, we crossed heterozygous VGLUT1vn/+ mice with EIIa-cre mice that express Cre recombinase in early embryonic stages (Lakso et al., 1996). Successfully recombined VGLUT1Venus alleles (v/+) in offspring from these interbreedings were genotyped by PCR (Fig. 1D). Except for initial comparative analyses of VGLUT1VenusNeo and VGLUT1Venus mice (Fig. 1), Cre recombined VGLUT1Venus mice were used for all experiments. All experiments were performed with littermates derived from crossing heterozygous VGLUT1v/+ or homozygous VGLUT1v/v mice (F2 SV129/ola × C57BL/6 genetic background). All live imaging experiments were performed on VGLUT1v/v mice. The probe used for embryonic stem (ES) cell screening by Southern blot was amplified from the VGLUT1 locus. It is located on the mouse chromosome 7 contig NT_039424.7 at position 6081938–6082223. The following oligonucleotides were used for genotyping PCRs: 9420, CTGGCTGGCAGTGACGAAAG; 9421, CGCTCAGGCTAGAGGTGTATGGA; 9423, CTTCAAGATCCGCCACAACATCG; 4174, CGCATCGCCTTCTATCGCCTTCTT. Oligonucleotides 9420 and 9421 were used to amplify the WT VGLUT1 allele, oligonucleotides 9421 and 9423 were used to amplify the VGLUT1v allele, and oligonucleotides 9421 and 4174 were used to amplify the VGLUT1vn allele.

(Herzog et. al. In vivo imaging of intersynaptic vesicle exchange using VGLUT1 Venus knock-in mice.  J Neurosci 2011 Oct 26: 31(43): 15544-59.  PMID: 22031900)GENERATION OF VGLUT1VENUS KI MICE.

comments.rationale: Using VGLUT1 Venus Knock In Mice, synaptosomes were purified using sucrose sedimentation followed by FAC sorting (titled Fluorescence Activated Synaptosome Sorting (FASS) in the paper).  Samples were then separated using SDS-PAGE and then analyzed by LC-MS/MS.

comments.species: Paper only specifies rat.
comments.rationale: The synaptic plasma membrane of the rat cerebral cortex was purified using a Percol gradient procedure.  (See additional literature.)  Western Blot indicated that annexin 1 was present in a 74 kDa form in the fraction.

comments.species: "...mice were processed for electron microscope pre-embedding immunogold labelling"
comments.rationale: Immunogold staining of CB1 receptors in the CA1 hippocampal region shows plasma membrane localized CB1 receptors. That staining is lost in CB1 knockout animals. Yellow arrows indicate plasma-membrane CB1 receptors.

comments.species: Both mice and rats are used. "Transverse hippocampal slices (300 microns) were obtained from Sprague-Dawley rats (P16-30) or C57BL6J mice."; "CB1+/+, CB1+/- and CB1−/− mice were of both genders and varied in age from 6 weeks to 8 months"
comments.rationale:
Figure 1C,D: Depolarization of CA1 postsynaptic pyramidal neurons mobilizes endocannabinoids, which retrogradely activate presynaptic CB1 receptors, transiently decreasing GABAergic inhibitory neurotransmission (depolarization-induced suppression of inhibition or DSI) or glutamatergic excitatory neurotransmission (depolarization-induced suppression of excitation or DSE). DSI is lost in CB1 knockout mice (Figure 1C,D). Additionally, DSE is lost in CB1 knockout mice (Figure 8A of Ohno-Shosaku, T. et al (2002) J Neurosci, 22(10), 3864-3872). 

Figure 3: In addition, evidence is shown that presynaptic N-Type Ca2+ channels are required for endocannabinoid signaling. DSI is occluded by a specific antagonist of N-type channels, ω-conotoxin GVIA, indicating a presynaptic requirement for N-type calcium channels in the regulation of GABAergic transmission by cannabinoids. Conversely, blocking P/Q-type channels results in increased DSI (removes a component of GABA release that is insensitive to DSI and therefore modulation of N-type calcium channels by cannabinoids is now very relevant).

comments.species:
The brains of adult male Sprague-Dawley rats (2 months old) were fixed and cut into coronal sections with a vibrating microtome.  
Mutant mice with targeted inactivation of Cav1.2 expression in the hippocampus (Cav1.2HCKO) were used in antibody verification.
comments.rationale:
Developed an antibody against the pore forming subunit of Cav1.2 that was used in light and electron microscopy of fixed and stained rat brain sections. 

Fig. 1 shows characterization and validation of antibody specificity. 

Immunoreactivity against the Cav1.2 pore-forming subunit (Cav1.2-IR) was observed in both myelinated and unmyelinated axons. Within labeled axons, Cav1.2-IR was either clustered or filled the intracellular space (Fig. 5A).

Axon terminals were also labeled, especially in CA1 stratum radiatum (Fig. 5B) and dentate gyrus (DG) stratum moleculare and least in CA3 stratum lucidum (Table 1). A majority of the labeled axon terminals formed asymmetric synapses. 

Cav1.2-IR was also observed in a large fraction of mossy fiber terminals in CA3 stratum lucidum and DG central hilus (Table 1), which generally formed asymmetric contacts with unlabeled dendrites (Fig. 5C,D). In these terminals, Cav1.2-IR formed clusters along the plasma membrane at synaptic and nonsynaptic sites but was also detected near nonsynaptic junctions with unlabeled dendrites resembling puncta adherentia. 

 21/6/2017 Pim
- I regard the predominant intracellular localization of Cav21 in these preparation as reflecting a non-canonical localization for this protein (protein synthesis, inactive pool) and I refrain from annotation of this localization.

comments.species: "Wild-type mice of either sex (C57BL/6 or CBA) postnatal 15–24 d were used for the majority of the experiments."
comments.rationale: Figure 2A: Paired recordings between synaptically connected cartwheel cells in the presence of GABA receptor antagonists SR95531 allow detecting glycinergic neurotransmission specifically, measuring IPSC. Glycinergic neurotransmission is acutely reduced when presynaptic surface glycine reuptake by GLYT2 is inhibited pharmacologically (ORG25543). IPSC amplitudes ran down soon after drug application (Fig. 2A), declining to 59 ± 11% of baseline within 10–11 min and 3 ± 1% of baseline within 30 min of drug application. Figure 2E: adding exogenous glycine to the whole-cell internal solution in the presynaptic cell occluded the rundown caused by GlyT2 block, showing that the ORG25543 effect was specifically due to loss of glycine availability in the presynaptic terminal. These results show that GLYT2 constitutively supplies glycine for refilling recycling vesicles.

comments.species:
Krox20 Cre/+;Actg LoxP/LoxP mice were created, which knocked out Actin, Gamma in the Calyx of Held.  200 uM parasaggital brain stem slices were cut for capacitance recordings.  Actg LoxP/LoxP were used as controls.    

Mouse hippocampal cultures were prepared using Actg LoxP/LoxP mice.  Mice were transfected with a Cre-mCherry plasmid to create knockout.

8/6/2017
The species of the over-expression construct (Fig.7) is not relevant for species selection since serving as control for specificity of loss of native mouse protein.
comments.rationale:
Whole cell patch recordings of P7-P10 calyxes at 22-24 oC were given a 20 ms depolarization from -80 mV to +10 mV.   The initial rate of decay of the capacitance change was significantly slower (~33% of control) in the Actin, Gamma KO suggesting a slower rate of endocytosis following vesicle fusion (Fig 2. A-C).    Similar results were observed when the stimulus was changed to a 20 action potential equivalent stimulus (Fig. 2 D-F), performed at 34-37 oC (Fig. 2 G) and in older mice (P13-P14) (Fig. 2 H).

Hippocampal neurons were cultured from the Actg LoxP/LoxP mice transfected with Synaptophysin-pHluorin2X (SypH) with or without a Cre containing plasmid (Fig. 6 A and D).  SypH can be used to study vesicle recycling as it is non-fluorescent in relatively low pH environment of vesicles but is fluorescent in the higher pH extracellular environment.  Upon stimulation the decay of fluorescence was significantly slower than the control (Fig. 6 E-G).  This fluorescence was quenchable by a low pH solution applied externally indicating it was not a deficit in vesicle reacidification, but instead suggesting that the vesicles had not been endocytosed (Fig. 6H).  This effect was rescued by transfecting Actg in the KO cultures (Fig 7 A,B). Taken together this data suggests that Actin, Gamma is important for endocytosis.      

.

comments.species: The annotation of ACTB is made against the human protein since a human OE protein was used; the neurons used were of rat origin.
comments.rationale:
The authors use a fluorescently labeled overexpression of human b-actin to study the dynamics (G-actin/F-actin transitions) of the actin cytoskeleton in dendritic spines. As inferred by the curator and based on the author's intent it is derived that the b-actin gene provides the structural basis of the F-actin skeleton at the postsynapse.

The "structural component" term is derived from Fig.4 where local application of the actin polymerization inhibitor Latrunculi A resulted in reduction of actin distribution in the synapse and the retraction of the spine. For this reason this term is not annotated against a IC evidence code.

comments.rationale:
The 5-HT transporter (SERT) is an integral membrane protein that transports 5-HT into cells in a sodium and chloride-dependent manner.

COS-1 cells were transfected to transiently express mouse SERT. Transport of radiolabelled [H3]5-HT into COS-1 cells (Fig.2a) is dependent on the extracellular sodium (Fig.3b) and chloride (Fig.2c) concentration.

comments.species: Adult male Sprague Dawley rats (250–400 gm) were purchased from Hilltop Laboratory Animals (Scottsdale, PA).
comments.rationale:
SERT immunoreactivity can be found on the plasma membrane in axon terminals (but not at the active zone) and in axons of serotonergic neurons, and rarely in dendrites and spines of neurons that are not 5-HT positive at the ultrastructural level.

Pre-embedding peroxidase labelling (Fig. 1) and immunogold-silver labelling of SERT was performed in the Nucleus accumbens (Nac). Immunogold-labelling demonstrates the presence of SERT on the plasma membrane in axons and axon terminals (Fig.2, 3, 4).

Antibodies: antipeptide (C611-630 and E387-401) and anti-fusion protein antisera (N1-85). In control experiments, samples were processed for immunoperoxidase or immunogold labelling with the omission of primary antisera or with antisera that have been pre-absorbed with the peptide. No KO-control.

comments.rationale:
Preembedding immuno-EM reveals the presence of immunoreactivityfor MARCKS in some axons and axon terminals in the cingulate cortex. 

MARCKS is myristoylated and interacts additionally via a cluster of basic residues through electrostatic interactions with the plasma membrane (myristoyl-electrostatic switch). comments.species:
We used a RNA interference (RNAi) approach to address the role of endogenous MARCKS in the maintenance of dendritic morphology. We first examined the pattern of MARCKS expression in 3-week-old cultures of rat hippocampus. 
Full-length bovine eGFP-tagged wild-type-MARCKS, and four MARCKS mutants were a gift from P. Blackshear (Spizz and Blackshear, 2001)
comments.rationale:
Rat hippocampal neurons expressing MARCKS RNAi constructs exhibit a greatly reduced spine density, spine length, and spine head width (Fig.1B). Efficiency of the KD was assessed by ICC (Fig. 1A).

MARCKS influences number of spines and spine morphology in a phosphorylation-dependent manner. Overexpression of MARCKS constructs that mimic constitutively phosphorylated MARCKS (S4D-MARCKS and Dbl-MARCKS) and therefore have reduced membrane-association than wildtype-MARCKS in neurons causes a reduced spine protrusion length and head width (Fig.2). 

Overexpression of a MARCKS construct that mimic constitutively phosphorylated MARCKS (S4D-MARCKS) causes a reduction in total F-actin in dendrites in comparison to control neurons (Fig. 3A,B).

comments.species:
Figure legend Fig. 4: PKC agonists or depolarization induce the phosphorylation of MacMARCKS in rat brain synaptosomes...
Figure legend Fig. 5: Proteins from rat brain subcellular fractions were fractionated...
comments.rationale:
In subcellular fractionation experiments of rat brain, MacMARCKS was enriched in soluble fractions (S3 and LS2), but also present in most membrane fractions, and in comparison to MARCKS also in the SV fraction (CPG-3) (Fig.5). 

In isolated synaptosomes, phosphorylation of MacMARCKS by PKC in response to stimulation by phorbol esters or depolarization-induced Ca2+-influx, induces a translocation of MacMARCKS from the membrane to the cytosol (Fig.4).

In NGF-differentiated PC12 cells, MacMARCKS colocalizes with the presynaptic marker Synaptophysin (Fig. 3). 

MacMARCKS is myristoylated and interacts with the plasma membrane. Therefore the term "anchored component of the presynaptic PM" was chosen.

Antibody: Affinity purified polyclonal antiserum against murine MacMARCKs. No KO-control.

comments.species: [...] a new-born rat brain cDNA library subcloned into the pAD vector were sequentially transformed into... To generate a MAcMARCKs expression plasmid, the entire coding sequence of MacMARCKs was amplified by PCR from the isolated pAD clone using...
comments.rationale:
MacMARCKS was identified as an interaction partner of the presynaptic metabotropic glutamate receptor mGluR7 in a Y2H screen. Endogenous mGluR7 can be immunoprecipitated from cultured cerebellar granule cells and MacMARCKs can be co-immunoprecipitated (Fig. 5a). Overexpression of myc-tagged mGluR7 and GFP-tagged MacMARCKS in cultured cerebellar granule cells induces localization of both proteins to the plasma membrane of the soma and dendrites as assessed by ICC (Fig. 5f). Expression of a mGluR7 mutant devoid of the binding domain to MacMARCKS (mGluR7(ΔMacMARCKS) causes a retention of MacMARCKS in the cytoplasm of the cell (Fig. 5g). 

mGluR7 is involved in promoting G-protein-mediated inhibition of voltage-sensitive calcium channels (VSCCs). Co-expression of mGluR7A and MacMARCKS in cultured cerebellar granule cells strongly reduces tonic inhibition of VSCCs (Fig. 6b1) indicating an indirect role of MacMARCKS for the regulation of voltage-cated calcium channel activity.

Antibody for WB was generated using purified GST-MacMARCKS fusion protein. Authors specify that the antibody was "not optimal for immunofluorescent labelling", therefore GFP-tagged MacMARCKS was overexpressed in cells for ICC. No KO-control.

25/8/2017 Pim
- The MacMARCKS protein is inferred to exert the function at the presynapse based on (1) the mentioned presynaptic localization of the mGLUR7 and (2) the presence of MacMARCKs/MRP/MARCKSL1 in brain synapses (ticket #833)

comments.species: We have produced, by means of in vivo homologous recombination, a strain of mice in which the gene encoding the DAT has been disrupted.
comments.rationale: The plasma membrane dopamine transporter (DAT) transports dopamine into neurons. Striatal synaptosomes from DAT-KO mice show no uptake of radiolabelled dopamine (Fig. 1d). Fast-scan cyclic voltammetry (carbon-fibre amperometry) after electrical stimulation in striatal DAT-KO slices reveals a 100times longer time for dopamine clearance in comparison to wildtype slices (Fig. 5). These findings indicate a defect in dopamine re-uptake in DAT-KO mice.

comments.species:
From M&M:
Postsynaptic density (PSD) fractions of the forebrain were obtained from Wistar rats.
For immunohistochemical examination at the light microscopic level, brains from Wistar rats were used.
comments.rationale: Authors examined the distribution of STAT3 in the rat brain. Using western blotting and subcellular fractionation authors found STAT3 immunoreactivity in the various subcellular fractions, including synaptic fractions. Then, they performed electron microscopy in the cerebral cortex with DAB enhancement, with and without post-staining to enhance visualization of some structures. By doing this, authors found PSDs and subsynaptic regions strongly labelled, though non-immunoreactive PSDs were also observed. Presynaptic terminals were not labelled.  Moreover, authors also found phosphorylation of STAT3 in PSD fractions, which suggest that STAT3 signaling occurs at postsynaptic sites.

comments.species: Here we report the molecular cloning, expression, deduced amino acid sequence, and apparent molecular size of the canine cardiac sarcolemmal Na+-Ca2+ exchange protein.
comments.rationale:
The paper reports the cloning of the Na+/Ca2+ exchanger (NCX1) from canine and characterizes its transporter activity.

Figure 1 reports an experiment where the NCX1 mRNA was injected in Xenopus oocytes (control- water injected). Na+ gradient-dependent labelled (45)Ca2+ uptake was measured under the following experimental conditions: 
-internal Na+ was elevated by incubation with nystatin.
- the external solution contained 10 uM of labelled CaCl2 in a K+ medium, in the absence of external Na+.

Under these conditions, the labeled Ca2+ uptake was at least one order of magnitude greater than control or than previously observed in oocytes injected with poly(A)+ RNA from cardiac tissue (PMID: 2462361).

When the external K+ ions were exchanged for Na+, or when the nystatin treatment was omitted, only background uptake levels were observed, indicating the need for a Na+ gradient for the Ca2+ uptake.

Taken together, the experiment demonstrates that the identified cDNA codes for a Na+/Ca2+ exchanger.

comments.species:
From M&M:
-Post-synaptic densities (PSDs) from rat hippocampus were used. 
-Hippocampal neuronal primary cultures were prepared from embryonic day 18–19 (E18-E19) rat hippocampi.
-Co-immunoprecipitation assay was done using hippocampi from adult rats.
-shRNA target gene for RNF10 was accession number NM_001011904.1.
- For viral constructs, human flag-RNF10 sequence was used.

14/6/2017 Pim
- Species of GFP-Rnf10 protein used in Fig.1/2 is not mentioned in the paper. I disregard information on this protein since the data on the endogenous protein is sufficient for annotation.
comments.rationale:
Authors found nuclear and somatodendritic immunoreactivity of RNF10. At the synapses, RNF10 colocalized with PSD95 as observed with confocal microscopy and subcellular fractionation followed by western blotting revealed RNF10 in synaptic fractions and strongly present in the PSD fraction. Moreover, authors described a direct interaction between RNF10 and GluN2A-containing NMDA receptors. By using pull down assays, they  described more in detail the binding region which is found in the N-terminal part of RNF10 and the GluN2A C-tail.

14/6/2017 Pim
- The "postsynaptic density" part is derived from the strong enrichment in the PSD fraction and the co-localization with PSD-95 (marker protein for PSD). The "extrinsic component of...." is derived from the colocalizaton with Glun2A (a transmembrane protein) and the ability to engage in direct PPI with Glun2A.

comments.species: 'Sprague–Dawley male adult albino rats (200–300 g) were used in these studies'
comments.rationale:
Ultrastructural localization of NCX1 in the cerebral cortex and hippocampus CA1. Preembedding immunoperoxidase and silver-enhanced immunogold procedures were used.
Figure 4b shows NCX1 immunoparticles associated to microtubules, mitochondria, and plasma membrane in several dendritic profiles.
Figure 4C shows dendritic spines labelled by the DAB reaction, indicating expression of NCX1. The corresponding axons are not labelled.
Figure 4D - particles associated with the membrane in the vicinity of the PSD in the CA1 stratum radiatum. 

Table 1 presents a quantification of the immunolabeling, and shows that a large portion of NCX1 profiles the cerebral cortex and in the hippocampus are in dendrites and spines.

Antibody:'NCX1 protein was detected by using a commercially available mouse monoclonal IgG antibody (R3F1; Swant, Bellinzona, Switzerland)'. Figure 1 demonstrated antibody specificity in western blotting of hippocampus, heart and cortex homogenates in comparison with a recombinant protein produced in HEK cells. Strong WB signals with little cross-reactivity are a good indication for the antibody specificity.

comments.species:
'A rat genomic library (Stratagene) was then screened with the 0.6-kb probe. Four genomic clones were isolated and subcloned into pBluescript SK’. Sequence analysis showed that one genomic clone, G23-2, overlapped with the 5’ end of pRll and also had an apparent codon for the initiating methionine'.

* 'We were initially unable to express NCX2 by injection of cRNA into Xenopus oocytes. We thus used the same strategy which improved expression of NCXl by replacing the 3’-untranslated region of NCXl with that of the Na+-glucose cotransporter clone which includes a poly(A)+tail'.
comments.rationale:
The paper reports the cloning and functional characterization of NCX2 as a Ca2+/Na+ exchanger. The authors use 'inside out' patches from Xenopus oocytes expressing NCX2. 
The patch pipette, facing the extracellular side, contains 8 mM Ca2+ and no Na+. 
The external solution, facing the cytoplasmic side of the membrane patch, contains 100 mM cesium. Figure 5a shows that a current can be elicited when the cesium is replaced by Na+, in the presence of 1, or 3 microMol Ca2+ in the external solution. When no Ca2+ is present at the external solution, no current is elicited, indicating a requirement of Ca2+ at the cytoplasmic domain of the exchanger.
Figure 5b shows that when the Ca2+ is removed from the external solution, the current decays.
Figure 5d shows the IV curve for the exchanger.

The data presented indicates a function for NCX2 as a Na+/Ca2+ exchanger that is dependent on the ion gradients.

comments.species:
A unique exchanger clone from a rat brain cDNA library was isolated.

* 'Therefore, we subcloned a poly(A)1-containing fragment of DNA into the BglII-NotI site of pIII (Fig. 1). This replaced most of the original NCX3 39-UTR with the 39-UTR derived from the SGLT1 (Na1-glucose cotransporter) clone (Hediger et al., 1987)'
as described previously (Li et al., 1994). The
comments.rationale:
The paper reports the cloning of the Na+/Ca2+ exchanger NCX3 and characterizes its transporter activity.

Figure 6a reports an experiment where the NCX3 mRNA was injected in Xenopus oocytes (control- water injected). Na+ gradient-dependent labelled (45)Ca2+ uptake was measured under the following experimental conditions: 
-internal Na+ was elevated by incubation with nystatin.
- the external solution contained labelled CaCl2 in a K+ medium, in the absence of external Na+.
Figure 6b presents the results of a similar experiment but in BHK cells. The cells were transfected with the NCX3 DNA (control - non transfected cells). The specific Na+-dependent uptake of (45)Ca2+ is plotted.

Under these conditions, the labeled Ca2+ uptake was larger than in the control. Background uptake levels were estimated by exchanging the external K+ ions for Na+, thereby eliminating the Na+ gradient which is necessary for Ca2+ uptake.

Taken together, the experiment demonstrates that the identified cDNA codes for a Na+/Ca2+ exchanger.

comments.species:
M&M: 
Male Wistar rats  4 weeks old were examined immunohistochemically at both the light and electron microscopic levels. 
Subcellular fractions of the brain were obtained from Wistar rats
comments.rationale:
Alpha-internexin is found in PSD fractions prepared from the rat forebrain but also cerebral cortex, hippocampus and cerebellum. The protein is present different subcellular compartments but enriched in the PSD fraction. No immunoreactivity was found in the soluble fraction. Moreover, alpha-internexin is also found in the neurofilament enriched fraction together with together with other neurofilament subunits, which suggests its tight association with neurofilaments. 
Electro microscopy analysis of samples immunostained with the antibody and visualized with diaminobenzidine revealed alpha-internexin immunoreactiviy in dendrites, spines and PSD were strongly immunoreactive. Importantly, these samples were not post stained with uranyl acetate to prevent unspecificity in the electron density labeling.  Not all PSDs were immunoreactive. Presynaptic terminals were not labelled.
Authors suggest based in the EM data and the high enrichment in the PSD fractions that alpha-internexin is a PSD constituent in vivo that may help in the organization of the PSD and mention, based on unpublished observations, that plectin, a cross-linker of intermediate filaments is present in the PSD fraction.

13/6/2017 Pim
- Authors speculate that intermediate filament localization to the PSD might represent a early developmental state in the formation of a postsynaptic specialization.

comments.species:
From M&M: Rabbit polyclonal antibodies specific for HAP1 were raised against a recombinant protein derived from a segment of the rat HAP1 (amino acids 287–452) fused to glutathione-S-transferase (GST) and affinity purified, as described previously (Li et al., 1995).
Adult male Sprague Dawley rats (n=6) were used for light microscopic immunocytochemistry. Five additional rats were used for both immunoperoxidase and pre- embedding immunogold electron microscopy experiments.
comments.rationale:
Authors used pre-embedding immunogold EM to study the cellular and subcellular localization of HAP1 in rat brain. They used a polyclonal antibody generated against the amino acids 287–452 from rat HAP1.
Electron micrographs show immunogold particles distributed among, and often on the cytoplasmic surface of synaptic vesicles in axon terminals as well as in postsynaptic dendritic spines.

comments.species: Characterization of NET-/- mice
comments.rationale:
The noradrenaline/norepinephrine transporter (NET) mediates noradrenaline uptake. 

NET-KO mice exhibit reduced binding of radiolabelled desipramine (a noradrenaline re-uptake inhibitor that binds NET) to brain membranes (Fig. 1d). Further, the authors state in the text that synaptosomes from cerebral cortex and cerebellum of NET-KO mice show no radiolabelled noradrenaline uptake, which could be inhibited by noradrenaline re-uptake inhibitors (data not shown). Cyclic voltammetry from tissue slices revealed that noradrenaline clearance after electrical stimulation is affected in NET-KO mice (Fig. 2c) and quantitative in vivo microdialysis showed that KO animals exhibit higher levels of extracellular noradrenaline levels (Fig. 2d).

comments.species:
Male Harlan Sprague-Dawley rats (100 g) were sacrificed by decapitation....
Long-Evans rat pups...
Adult male Harlan Sprague-Dawley rats were anesthetized with Nembutal (50 mg/kg) and perfused intracardially...
comments.rationale:
The noradrenaline/norepinephrine transporter (NET) is an integral component of the plasma membranes in axons and axon terminals. 

In cultured SCG neurons, NET-immunoreactivity is localized to axons. ICC demonstrated co-localiation of NET with the synaptic vesicle marker synaptophysin, indicating a presynaptic localization (Fig.10). Pre-embedding immuno-EM using an antibody directed to an intracellular epitope revealed immunoreactivity for NET along the cytoplasmic side of the plasma membrane and within the cytoplasm on synaptic vesicles (Fig.11).

In the study, a rabbit polyclonal NET antisera was raised against the peptide WERVAYGITPENEHHLVAQRDVR (amino acids 585–607, peptide N585). The specificity of the antibody was validated by immunoprecipitation, immunoblot and immunohistochemistry (Fig.1). No KO-control.

comments.rationale:
The noradrenaline/norepinephrine transporter (NET) is localized to synaptic vesicles in axon terminals. 

In cultured SCG neurons, NET-immunoreactivity is localized to axons. ICC demonstrated co-localiation of NET with the synaptic vesicle marker synaptophysin, indicating a presynaptic localization (Fig.10). Pre-embedding immuno-EM using an antibody directed to an intracellular epitope revealed immunoreactivity for NET along the cytoplasmic side of the plasma membrane and within the cytoplasm on synaptic vesicles (Fig.11).

In the study, a rabbit polyclonal NET antisera was raised against the peptide WERVAYGITPENEHHLVAQRDVR (amino acids 585–607, peptide N585). The specificity of the antibody was validated by immunoprecipitation, immunoblot and immunohistochemistry (Fig.1). No KO-control.

comments.species: Rat VAChT cDNA or synthetic mRNA prepared from the cDNA was injected into one of the early blastomeres of Xenopus embryos at the 2-cell stage...
comments.rationale: Injection of rat VAChT cDNA or synthetic mRNA into blastomeres of Xenopus embryos causes an overexpression of VAChT at the developing neuromuscular synapse, which is known to exhibit incomplete ACh filling of synaptic vesicles at this immature stage. Overexpression of VAChT in the presynaptic neurons causes an increase in the amplitude and frequency of spontaneous (action-potential independent) miniature excitatory postsynaptic currents measured by whole cell patch-clamp electrophysiology in postsynaptic muscle cells (Fig. 2). These findings indicate that VAChT regulates the neurotransmitter filling state of synaptic vesicles.

comments.species: Adult male Sprague-Dawley rats (n = 8) were given 300 IU of heparin i.p., deeply anesthetized with ...
comments.rationale:
Pre-embedding immunoperoxidase and immunogold electron microscopy VAChT immunoreactivity in presynaptic terminals (Fig. 4c,d,e) and on synaptic vesicles (Fig. 4f,g,h), respectively.

A rabbit polyclonal antibody directed against the C-terminus of VAChT was generated in the study. The specificity of the antibody was tested by Western Blotting (Fig. 1) and immunohistochemistry (Fig. 3 a,b). No KO-control.

comments.species: Expression vectors for full length rat msec7-1 were generated
comments.rationale: mSec7-1 is a guanine nucleotide exchange factor (GEF). Overexpression of rat msec7-1 in Xenopus neuromuscular junctions causes and increase in the frequency of spontaneous synaptic currents (Fig. 3), without a change in the number of synaptic terminals (data not shown), indicating the the presence of a larger readily releasable pool (Fig. 3). Overexpression of msec7-1 caused an increase in amplitude of the the initial action-potential evoked EPSC. These data indicate a function of msec7-1 in regulating synaptic vesicle exocytosis.

comments.species:
- Fig.1 Expression vectors for full length rat msec7-1 were generated...
- Fig. 2 Synaptic localization shown with Xenopus cell culture that overexpresses rat mSec.
comments.rationale: Overexpressed GFP-tagged msec7-1 is localized to presynaptic regions in Xenopus neuromuscular junctions (Fig. 2). Overexpression of msec7-1 causes a translocation of ARF6 from endosomal compartments to the plasma membrane in HEK293 cells (Fig. 1). mSec7-1 contains a pleckstrin-homology domain, which mediates an enhancement of the GEF activity by its binding to PIP2.

comments.species: Adult rat whole brains were homogenized and fractionated into cytosols and P1 and P2 membrane fractions...
comments.rationale:
In purified synaptosomes from rat brain, cytohesin-2 interacts with the PDZ domain-containing protein tamalin, which binds mGluR1 at the postsynaptic membrane. The binding of cytohesin-2 to tamalin was identified in a Y2H screen. Cytohesin-2 is enriched in PSD-fractions (Fig. 6a). PSD-95 and mGluR1 were mostly enriched in the PSDIII fraction, whereas tamalin and cytohesin-2 were enriched in the PSDII fraction, indicating a more loosely association with postsynaptic membranes. 

Antibody: Rabbit cytohesin-2 antisera were raised against an N-terminal sequence (aa 1-26). The antibody exhibited some (<5%) cross-reactivity with cytohesin-1 and -3. No KO-control

The paper examines the localization of kappa-type opioid receptor in dopaminergic terminals at the nucleus Accumbens using electron microscopic immunocytochemistry.

comments.species:
'Saturation binding of [3H]diprenorphine using COS-7 cell membranes.
[3H]Diprenorphine binding was determined using membranes
prepared from COS-7 cells transfected with either the rat MOR-i cDNA
plasmid or the parental vector.'
comments.rationale:
The paper reposts the cloning and functional expression of the Mu-type opioid receptors. Figure 2 demonstrates that COS-7 cells transfected with the cDNA coding for the Mu-type opioid receptor can bind [3H]Diprenorphine (an opioid receptor agonist) in a dose-dependent and saturable manner. Cells transfected with the empty vector show no binding.
Figure 3  presents displacement experiments of [3H]Diprenorphine binding by various unlabeled ligands. Table 1 presents lC50 values calculated based on the efficiency of displacement. DAGO, a mu-type selective agonist was the most efficient in displacing [3H]Diprenorphine binding, whereas kappa-type selective ligands (e.g. U-50488) or delta-type selective (e.g. DSLET) were inefficient in displacing. 
Figure 4 demonstrated that the activity of the receptor is coupled to intracellular signaling: cAMP levels were measured in COS-7 cells expressing the receptor or in non-transfected COS-7 cells. The cells were stimulated with the adenylyl cyclase activator Forskolin and in parallel with the mu-type receptor agonist DAGO. This combination lead to a circa 20% reduction in the cAMP levels. The effect was blocked by the mu-type selective antagonist naloxonazine. This experiment demonstrates a role for the receptor in intracellular signaling.

comments.species: 'Seven adult male Sprague Dawley rats (250–350 gm; Taconic, Germantown, NY) were anesthetized with sodium pentobarbital (100 mg/kg, i.p.).'
comments.rationale:
The paper characterizes the sub cellular localization of both mu-type and delta-type opioid receptors using immuogold-silver and peroxidase labelling.
Figure 1 is a quantification of the labelled profiles, sowing a significant labeling at the presynaptic terminal.
Figure 2 presents a quantification, showing that in labelled terminals, a large proportion of mu-tpye immunolabeling is at the membrane, but not in the active zone region.
Figure 5c,d show two profiles of axons with mu-type immunoreactivity.
Figure 6 is a scheme illustrating the main sub cellular localization of the receptors.

- A wealth of species is used in this paper. I have selected *mouse* as annotated species because biochem data and EM data are both available for this species.
comments.rationale: By tissue fractionation of mouse whole brain [Fig2] or human post mortem hippocampus [Fig3], DTNBP1 (Dysbindin-1) is found concentrated in the synaptosome and synaptic vesicle fractions, with little protein in the PSD fraction. Immuno-EM (qualitative) confirmed presynaptic vesicle localisation in the mouse and macaque dentate gyrus inner molecular layer [Fig5] and CA1 [Fig8A & B], and the dentate gyrus hilus of the mouse [Fig6C]. Postsynaptic density localisation was also detected in the dentate gyrus hilus [Fig6B & D] mossy fiber synapse [Fig7] and in the CA1 area of mouse [Fig8D & E].

comments.species: adult C57BL/6 mice
Mint1/2 double KO mice were studied.
comments.rationale:
Mint1 likely functions redundantly with Mint2 in excitatory neurons to regulate presynaptic release at excitatory synapses.
Fig. 5 shows that Mint1/2 DKO mice but not single Mint1 KO mice exhibit reduced basal excitatory synaptic strength and a decrease in neurotransmitter release probability at excitatory synapses. 
Fig. 6 shows that release probability is normal at inhibitory synapses of Mint1/2 DKO mice.
Fig. 7 shows that Mint1/2 DKO mice have reduced mEPSC frequency.

comments.species: Mint1/2 double KO mice were studied.
comments.rationale:
Mint2 likely functions redundantly with Mint1 in excitatory neurons to regulate presynaptic release at excitatory synapses.
Fig. 5 shows that Mint1/2 DKO mice but not single Mint1 KO mice exhibit reduced basal excitatory synaptic strength and a decrease in neurotransmitter release probability at excitatory synapses. 
Fig. 6 shows that release probability is normal at inhibitory synapses of Mint1/2 DKO mice.
Fig. 7 shows that Mint1/2 DKO mice have reduced mEPSC frequency.

comments.species: Mint1 KO mice were studied.
comments.rationale:
Mint1 regulates inhibitory transmission and Fig. 7 shows that Mint1 KO mice exhibit paired-pulse depression of IPSCs. This supports an impairment in the regulation of GABA release and release probability.

Single KO of Mint1 does not impair excitatory transmission as shown in Fig. 5 but the additionally referenced annotation demonstrates that Mint1 acts redundantly with Mint2 to control presynaptic release at excitatory synapses.

The paper describes the subcellular localization of delta-type opioid receptors in the axon terminals of the cervical spinal cord.

Figure 3 and 5a shows that in axon terminals, immunoreactivity is localized to the membranes and lumen of dense-core vesicles (Fig. 3) at the peripheral

The paper reports that in axon terminals, immunoperoxidase could also be localized to membranes of numerous small clear vesicles.

comments.species: Materials and Methods. "Primary neuronal cultures were prepared from cortices of embryonic day (E) 17 or postnatal day (P) 1 rats."
comments.rationale: Confocal images of neurons stained with antibodies against APBB1/Fe65 and synaptophysin shows colocalisation of both proteins in a synaptic staining pattern. Live-imaging experiments further illustrate punctate colocalisation of APBB1-EGFP and with synaptobrevin-DsRed puncta in axons.

comments.species: Polymerase chain reaction (PCR) was carried out with an aliquot (-1 x 106 plaqueforming units) of a mouse brain cDNA library (Clontech; catalogue no. ML1036a) as a template.
comments.rationale:
The paper describes the cloning and functional expression of the delta-type opioid receptor. 
Table 1 summarized the results of an experiment where the specific binding of (3H)-Naltrindole, a delta-type receptor antagonist, to membranes of COS-7 cells transfected with the cDNA (or controls) was measured. Binding was detected only to transfected membranes. Unlabelled ligands that are known to activate delta-type receptors were efficient in inhibiting the binding of (3H)-Naltrindole, whereas ligands specific to other types of opioid receptors were inefficient.

* The text reports that the identified receptors are coupled to G proteins:
1. Since GTP decreased the binding of the delta-specific agonist [3H]DPDPE.
2. Since the delta-specific agonists DPDPE and DSLET inhibited forskolin-stimulated cAMP formation in COS-1 cells expressing the delta-receptor by 70%.

Taken together, the paper identifies a opioid receptor with G-protein signaling properties.

comments.species:
'Figure 6... Results from double-labelling of an MNTB section from a
P10 rat, incubated with anti Rab-3A and anti-CB antibodies, are shown.'
comments.rationale:
The paper is describing the expression pattern of Ca2+ binding proteins in the calyx of Held synapse using conventional immunostaining. The calyx of Held is a giant synapse where a clear separation of can be made between the pre and postsynaptic compartments using standard confocal microscopy.
Figure 6 describes the results of a double immuostaining for Rab3 (a presynaptic marker) and calbindin. The staining for calbindin is restricted to the postsynaptic compartment, diffused (Fig. 6A), and does not co-localize with the Rab3 staining (Figure 6B,C).

1/7/2017 Pim
Cytosolic localization is inferred from the diffuse staining of the protein.

comments.species: For electron microscopy, two rats were perfused with 4.0% paraformaldehyde-0.2% glutaraldehyde in PB and post-fixed in 4.0% paraformaldehyde for 4–6 hours at 4°C, and three rats were perfused with 2.0% paraformaldehyde-3.75% acrolein and post-fixed in 2% paraformaldehyde for 3 hours.
comments.rationale:
The paper describes the synaptic connectivity of interneuronal subpopulations in the rat basolateral amygdalar nucleus.
Figures 3, 4 and 5 show that immunoperoxidase reactivity labelling calbindin is diffused and found in presynaptic terminals.

2/7/2017 Pim
- Cytosol localization derived from the diffuse, non-localized staining.

comments.species: 'Electrophysiology: hippocampal slices of 250 microM thickness were prepared from the brains of 14-day-old C57Bl6 and CB knock out mice killed by decapitation.'
comments.rationale:
The paper elegantly characterized the role of calbindin as a Ca2+ buffer at the presynaptic compartment of multipolar bursting interneurons in the mouse neocortex. Paired whole cell recordings of presynaptic interneurons synapsing on pyramidal cells in layer 2/3 were made. 
In WT pairs, paired-pulse facilitation of the IPSPs is seen when two depolarizations are given with a 10 Hz frequency (Fig 2A left). After a long recordings, the first IPSC is increased in amplitude and the PPF is reduced (Figure 2A right and 2B left). 
In calbindin KOs, the first IPSC amplitude is increased already at the start of the recordings, the initial PPF is reduced (2C left and 2B right), and there is no change following long recordings (2B left).
These data suggest that in WT cells, a Ca2+ buffer in the presynapse limits the size of the first IPSC and leads to a strong PPF. During the long recordings the buffer is washed out into the recording electrode, the first IPSC amplitudes increases in size and the PPF is reduced. 
Figure 2C (right) shows that calbindin loading in the presynaptic compartment of the knockout interneuron reduces the amplitude of first IPSP and restores facilitation. There is little effect of the loading in WT synapses.
Figure 3 A and B show similar effects on the initial IPSC amplitude and on the PPR when loading a WT terminal where the endogenous Ca2+ buffer has been washed out with the fast Ca2+-buffer BAPTA.
Taken together, these data demonstrate a role for calbindin as a Ca2+ buffer regulating presynaptic Ca2+ concentrations, basal release probability and short-term synaptic plasticity at the presynapse of interneurons.

In figure 5 and 6 similar effects are documented in CA3 mossy fiber calbindin KO synapses.

comments.species:
Hippocampal cell cultures were prepared and maintained as described in Lu et al. (1998). Briefly, hippocampal cells from 21-day old embryonic Sprague-Dawley
rats were dissociated and grown on top of a feeder layer of glial cells for 3–4 weeks.
comments.rationale:
The paper uses immunogold electron microscopy to define the localization of Calcium /Calmodulin kinase II alpha in pre- and postsynaptic terminals at rest and following neuronal activity induced by high K+.
Figure 2 presents a quantification of the distribution of a-CaMKII immunolabel in three regions of the synapse. A significant fraction of particles can be found in the 200 nm region proximal to the presynatpic membrane and at the dendritic spine.
Figures 3a,b show immunogold labeling for a-CaMKII at the periphery of the synaptic vesicle clusters and at the postsynaptic compartment.
Figures 4c, d show that immunogold labeling of a-CaMKII is localized at the edge of clustered synaptic vesicles in control terminals (C), but after high K+, label
becomes intermingled with declustered vesicle (D).
Figures 5a,b show that a-CaMKII immunogold labeling becomes redistributed closer to the active zone after high K+ depolarization.

comments.species: Subcellular fractions enriched in postsynaptic densities were obtained from rat brains by using a slightly modified version of the protocol developed by Cohen et al. (1977).
comments.rationale:
The paper characterizes the localization of Calcium /Calmodulin kinase II beta and alpha in isolated post-synaptic density fractions.

Figure 8 presents a quantification of the immunogold labeling as a function of age. Substantial labeling densities are present for both isoforms.

Table 2 presents the summary of the immunogold labeling quantifications.

Figure 1 presents the antibodies used. For all experiments, a negative control was made in the absence of primary antibody. The small amount of non-specific labeling was quantified and subtracted as background. 

Figure S1 presents western blots for each of the antibodies. A single band is seen for the CaMKII alpha and beta, however, the blots are cropped so specificity evaluation is difficult.

- The isolated also contain NMDAR subunits so in ference to the cytoplasmic part of the PSD is not valid.

comments.species:
M&M:
-Pregnant Oncins France souche A (OFA; a substrain of Sprague Dawley) rats (Charles River) were used for primary neuron cultures, and 2-month-old OFA rats of both sexes were used for biochemical analysis of brain tissue.
-Three-month-old male C57BL/6 mice and 1.3-month-old female Chmp2b KO mice(here called KD mice since knock-out is incomplete; Ghazi-Noori et al., 2012) or female WT littermates (on C57BL/6 background) were used for immunohistochemistry and electron microscopy (EM) studies.
- From Belly et al., 2010, where shRNA was described: The shRNA targeted the rat CHMP2B sequence at positions 578–596 (5 - GACACTACAAACAATGCAG-3 ) according to Lee et al. (Lee et al., 2007) and the encoding oligonucleotide was cloned between the HindIII and BglII sites of pSuper– mCherry.
comments.rationale: CHMP2B is found in dendritic shafts and spines where it colocalizes with PSD-95 as observed using confocal microscopy. Immunogold EM revealed significantly increased immunoreactivity in spines, where particles arranged beneath the spine membrane around the PSD. Subcellular fractionation revealed enrichment in membranes and synaptoneurosomes and PSD fractions, but could be solubilized from the PSD fraction by using Sarkosyl.   Immunoprecipitation of CHMP2B from synaptoneurosomes also precipitates PSD scaffolds and this was also confirmed by mass spectrometry.

comments.rationale: ced5 mutants exhibit synaptic vesicle clustering defects in AIY interneurons (assessed using confocal microscopy imaging of wild type and mutant worms expressing RAB3-GFP). CED5 effect on SV clustering depends on UNC-40 localisation. CED5 acts through the GTPase CED10 and, in turn, through MIG10. Like ced5 mutants, both ced10 (Figs 3H, I and N) and mig10 mutants (Figs 4C, E and F) also display SV clustering defects that may occur via organisation of presynaptic actin. Neither ced5 nor mig10 mutants affect localisation of active zone proteins SYD1 and SYD2.

comments.species: Whole cochleae were dissected from rats and immediately perfused through the round window with 4% paraformaldehyde (PFA) in phosphate-buffered saline (PBS) at pH 7.4.
comments.rationale:
The paper studies the distribution of NKAα1 and NKAα3 in the rat spiral ganglion and in the organ of Corti

Figure 5 demonstrates membrane staining for NKAα3 directly surrounding cytoplasmatic synpasin staining at the bouton-shaped terminals of the medial olivocochlear efferents that contact the outer hair cells (Fig. 5D-I). The expression of synapsin is known to label these presynapses.

Double labeling of organs of Corti with a monoclonal anti-NKAα3 (Fig. 5A) and a polyclonal anti-prestin (Fig. 5B), a protein enriched in the cell membrane of the postsynaptic OHCs, shows the NKAα3-positive fibers traveling through the tunnel of Corti and contacting the OHCs with their bouton-shaped terminals (Fig. 5C). There is no apparent postsynaptic labelling.

These staining support a presynaptic membrane localization of the NKAα3.

comments.species: Male WT and CaMKIV/Gr KO littermate mice at 6–8 weeks of age were anesthetized with inhaled halothane.
comments.rationale:
The paper examines the implications of the targeted deletion of Calcium /Calmodulin kinase IV. 

Figure 3C and figure 5B show impairment in LTP in CA1 neurons. The impairment is stronger if four tetanic stimulations are used (5B, in comparison to two stimulations in 3C).
Figure 3D: no effect is seen on LTD in CA1 neurons.
Figure 6 shows basal and depolarization-induced phosphorylation of CREB in primary cortical neurons of KO, het and WT E14 mice. Phosphorylation is low in the non-stimulated neurons but is dramatically increased upon depolarization of WT and HET neurons. No change is seen in the KO samples, implying that the major activity-dependent kinase phosphorylating CREB is Calcium /Calmodulin kinase IV.
Figure 7A,C show (A) and quantify (C) decreased phospho-CREB staining of CA1 neurons of glutamate-perfused hippocampal slices of KO mice compared with WT littermates.
Figure 5 and table 1 demonstrate an effect of Calcium /Calmodulin kinase IV KO on synaptic transmission and on LTD in cultured cultured Purkinje neurons. The effect is seen only at the late phase of LTP.

Taking together, the paper shows that Calcium /Calmodulin kinase IV is necessary for the phosphorylation of CREB, and that Calcium /Calmodulin kinase IV signaling is important for the generation of proper LTP/LTD.

comments.species:
In figure 1, to produce the recombinant CaMKIIb, a Rat construct is used: 'Baculoviral expression vectors for rat CaMKII  and -  have been reported'
Figure 4: 'Untagged rat CaMKII alpha and beta were expressed by using Clontech’s pEGFP-C1 vector by replacing the coding region of EGFP with respective cDNAs. Deletion mutants were constructed by PCR-mediated method and expressed by using pCMV-myc expression vector (Clontech).'
comments.rationale:
The paper examines the role of CaMKIIb in the bundling of filamentous actin.

Figure 1a shows that CaMKIIb can bundle F-actin - F-actin formed in vitro was incubated with purified CaMKIIalpha/beta , alpha , or beta. The reaction product was sedimented, so that the linear, unbundled F-actin stays in supernatant but bundled F-actin sediments.  CaMKIIb was pulled-down with the bundled F-actin while the  CaMKIIalpha stayed in the supernatant, indicating an interaction between bundled F-actin and CaMKIIb. 

Figure 1b shows a dose-dependent bundling of F-actin by CaMKIIb.

Figure 1c shows negatively stained electron micrographs of F-actin in the presence or absence of purified CaMKIIalpha or CaMKIIb. A clear and strong effect is seen on F-actin bundling when it is incubated with CaMKIIb.

Figure 4 shows in-vivo that the interaction between actin and CaMKII slows down the turnover of actin in the dendritic spine. FRAP (fluorescent recovery after photobleaching assay in organotypic hippocampal slices was used to monitor the turnover of actin molecules in dendritic spines. CaMKIIb and GFP-actin were overexpressed. This likely results in CaMKII oligomers that are rich in CaMKIIb. GFP-actin in a single dendritic spine was photobleached and thereafter the recovery of its fluorescence was monitored (Fig. 4a-c). The over expression of CaMKIIb lead to a significantly slower turnover of GFP-actin. CaMKIIalpha, and a deletion mutant of CaMKIIb that does not contain the actin binding site did not have an effect on the recovery time constant (Fig. 4D, E).  The conclusion that can be derived here is that CaMKIIb overexpression specifically leads to a slower turnover of actin at dendritic spines.

1/7/2017 Pim
- Important is that the bundling activity of CamKIIb does not depend on its kinase activity (Fig.3)
- Activation of CamKII is associated with loss of the bundling activity (Fig.5).
- "CaMKIIβ but Not -α Is Necessary for Maintaining Synaptic Structure"
- Figure 3: The authors show that there are more filopodia and less 'mature dendritic spines' when CaMKII beta is knocked-down.

comments.rationale:
Dynorphins are agonists of the kappa-opioid receptors. The pro-peptide, called Proenkephalin-B or Preprodynorphin is cleaved into 9 hormone-like peptides, one of which is Dynorphin A (1-8).
The paper presents pre-embedding immunoperoxidase-based electron microscopy analysis and shows that Dynorphin A (1-8) is a presynaptic peptide associates with the rims of small SVs (Figure 4-6, very clear in figure 6b) and with the core of large-dense core vesicles.

comments.species: Four adult  male Sprague-Dawley rats (Taconic Farms, NJ; 200-250  g) were  used  in  this  study.
comments.rationale:
Proenkephalin-A is a precursor that is cleaved into 8 peptides, of which Met-enkephalin is one. Met-enkephalin is a major agonist of the Mu-opioid receptor.

The paper uses pre-embedding peroxidase immunostaining for electron microscopy to characterize the location of Met5-enkephalin in the rat Nucleus locus coeruleus. The majority of the peroxidase signal is found in presynaptic profiles (examples in figure 2-4). In the presynapse,  strong signal was found associated with large-dense core vesicles (examples in figure 2-4). There was also peroxidase signal in the rim of small synaptic vesicles (figure 2 and text) in a subset of labelled terminals. Occasionally plasma membrane immunoreactivity was detected.

comments.rationale: CRTC1 localizes in dendritic spines and translocates to the nucleus upon bicuculline application, which requires functional AMPA and NMDA receptors. This process occurs in excitatory but not GAD67 positive neurons. In organotypic and acute slices, translocation of CRTC1 is also found after induction of cLTP or theta pulse stimulation. In both cases, the observation was made in the CA1 region. Reduction of CRTC1 levels by means of a siRNA affected the CREB-induced expression of some but not all genes.

comments.rationale:
Abi-1 is found in the cytoplasm where it concentrates at PSDs and in the nucleus in NIH cells and also in hippocampal neurons. NMDA treatment induced an enhancement of nuclear Abi-1 staining which was accompanied by a decrease in the synaptic staining. This effect was also found in hippocampal neurons from acute rat brain slices. Moreover, WB analysis revealed an slight enrichment of Abi-1 in the nuclear fraction upon NMDA treatment. Nuclear translocation was prevented by treatment with colchicine or cytochalasinD, which suggests that the transport depends on microtubules and microfilaments. Nuclear entry seems to rely on Abi-1 phosphorylation of Y53 while synaptic localization seems to rely on the SH3 domain. 
Finally,  Abi-1 influences transcriptional activity at the E-box regulated promoters in HeLa cells after EGF stimulation as part of a complex with Myc/Max.

comments.species: Our S‐synaptosome preparation was adapted from two previously published protocols (Hebb & Whittaker, 1958; Huttner et al, 1983). Briefly, forebrains of one or two mice were homogenized in 4 ml of ice‐cold homogenization buffer (0.32 M Sucrose, 4 mM HEPES pH 7.4, 1 μM PMSF, 1 μg/ml Aprotinin, 1 μg/ml Leupeptin) using a 5‐ml glass‐Teflon homogenizer with 12 gentle strokes.
comments.rationale:
The authors used synaptosomes derived from vGlut-Venus knockin mice to enrich for glutamatergic presynaptic terminals. Mass spectrometry was performed to detect protein content, which identified PPP2R1A. Although this method favors the detection of presynaptic proteins, postsynaptic or extrasynaptic localization of PPR2R1A cannot be excluded with this method.

comments.species: Hippocampal primary cultures were prepared from rat embryos.
comments.rationale:
AIDA-1 is present in dendritic spines, where it colocalizes with PSD-95, but also in the nucleus, often associated with Cajal bodies. AIDA-1 enters the nucleus in response to activity, and this is only prevented by blockade of NMDA receptors, which suggest that NMDA receptor activation triggers AIDA-1 nuclear translocation. Nevertheless, this translocation seems to be independent of intracellular calcium. Upon NMDA receptor activation, AIDA-1 undergoes proteolytic cleavage and the N terminus of the protein shuttles to the nucleus where the C terminus remains as observed by WB using antibodies specific for both protein regions. In this way,the N terminal region is enriched in the nuclear fraction while the C terminus is enriched in the PSD fraction. 
siRNA-mediated reduction of AIDA-1 levels significatively reduced protein translation induced by Bicuculine, in agreement with a role of  AIDA-1 in regulating nuclear protein synthesis.

comments.species: * there is no specified species, the peptide was purchased from 'Endolabs', which does not seem to exist anymore. The sequence of the peptide would be identical whether rat, mouse or human sequences are used.
comments.rationale:
The paper describes a negative signaling pathway induced by Met-enkephalin, a peptide that binds to the Mu-type opioid-receptor and is produced by the cleavage of Proenkephalin-A and stored in synaptic LDCVs (see CC annotation 963).

The paper characterizes the dopamine-induced release of the LH-releasing hormone (LHRH) in the postal MBH (a hypothalamic subcompartment). Figure 1 presents an experiment, where the release of LHRH is monitored, with and without the addition of external Dopamine or external Met- enkephalin. The addition of Dopamine increases LHRH release, while the addition of Met- enkephalin has no effect. The combined addition of Dopamine and Met- enkephalin inhibits the Dopamine-dependent augmentation of LHRH release. 

In Figure 2, Naloxone, an Opioid receptor antagonist, is added in parallel to Met- enkephalin and dopamine, and the effect of Met- enkephalin on Dopamine-dependent augmentation of LHRH release is blocked, indicating that the effect is via opioid receptors.

Since Met- enkephalin by itself does not negatively interfere with LHRH release, a possible interpretation of these observations is that Met- enkephalin signaling negatively interferes with the effect of Dopamine-mediated signaling.

23/8/2017 Pim
- Authors state in the Intro "Dopamine (DA) has been found to simulate the release of LHRH from ... a synaptosomal fraction of the MBH (Bennett et al., Nature 257, 323 (1975))" This shows that the dopamine (exogenously applied in the primary paper) is released from synapses. We can file the data in this paper under 'synaptic signaling'.

comments.species:
From the supplemental file:
'To study the role of presynaptic αCaMKII, we made use of a αCaMKII mutant, in which αCaMKII exon 2 is deleted7. Exon 2 encodes the catalytic site, and deletion of this exon results in a premature translation stop due to a frame shift, thus effectively resulting in a αCaMKII knock-out (KO) line7.' 'All mice were obtained by breeding heterozygous parents.'
comments.rationale:
Figure 3 shows that by quantitative electron microscopy that in slices from αCaMKII KO mice, asymmetric synapses on dendritic spines of CA1 pyramidal neurons, the number of docked vesicles is increased. Figure S4 shows example images.

Figure 2d show that during a 10 Hz train, the depletion rate of SVs is lower in slices from αCaMKII KO mice. 

Taken together, these data point to a regulatory role of αCaMKII on synaptic vesicle docking.

comments.species:
From M&M:
-Post-synaptic densities (PSDs) from rat hippocampus were used. 
-Hippocampal neuronal primary cultures were prepared from embryonic day 18–19 (E18-E19) rat hippocampi.
-Co-immunoprecipitation assay was done using hippocampi from adult rats.
-shRNA target gene for RNF10 was accession number NM_001011904.1.
- For viral constructs, human flag-RNF10 sequence was used.
- The sequence for the RNF10-tdEOS is not specified.
comments.rationale:
RNF-10 is a protein with synaptic and nuclear localization that contains two NLS within its sequence, suggesting its role as a synaptonuclear messenger. Treatment with Bicuculine to increase network activity induced a reduction of RNF-10 immunoreactivity in synapses and a simultaneous enhancement in the nucleus. This effect is nicely monitored by using an photo convertible RNF-10, which is photo converted in distal dendrites upon application of bicuculine and whose fluorescence can be observe in the nucleus over time. Translocation of RNF10 is dependent on activation of synaptic NMDA receptors.
Interestingly, RNF10 can interact with importins alpha, and bicuculin treatment enhanced the interaction between RNF10 and importin alpha1, suggesting an importin-dependent nuclear translocation of RNF10. 
Photoconversion experiments performed after induction of LTP using field stimulation reveals that RNF10 accumulated in the nucleus after long distance protein transport. This was corroborated using a different approach in which levels of RNF10 in the nuclear fraction were assessed after induction of cLTP in primary hippocampal cultures, which revealed an enrichment of RNF10. Finally, downregulation of RNF10 levels by means of a shRNA revealed that lacking of RNF10 prevented expression of target genes such as p21waf/cip1 and Ophn1.

comments.species: 'Animals: ICR mice and newly hatched chickens were used'
comments.rationale:
The paper examines the localization of alphaN-Catenin and Beta-Catenin using pre-embedding immunogold labeling for electron micropscopy. Catenins are cytoplasmatic proteins that bind the Cadherin family of transmembrane proteins.

Figure 3: localization in the adult cerebellar nucleus. 3B, 3C: Immunogold staining for alphaN-catenin, showing clusters of alphaN-catenin localized at the synaptic junctions nearby both the pre- the postsynaptic plasma membranes. The clusters appear to be located at the rim of transmitter release zones and are associated
with synaptic vesicle clusters (Fig. 3, B and D).

Figure 4: analysis at the cerebral cortex: in axo-spinous synapses (Fig. 4 A, C, D), the immunolabeling was bordering the release sites. In axo-dendritic and axo-somatic synapses (4E,F), aN-catenin signals tended to overlap synaptic vesicle clusters.

Figure 6 shows immunolabelling for alphaN-catenin in developing brains (P10). The labelling is at both sides of the synapse, associated with contact sites, but more diffused, i.e. not segregates to the borders of the release site.

The above findings suggest both a pre- and postsynaptic localization for alphaN-Catenin, with a large portion of the signal localized at the rims of the postsynaptic membrane.

*Antibody: NCAT5: 'reacted specifically with aN-catenin but not with alphaE-catenin,'

comments.species: "Experiments were performed on adult (3–5 months old) male Sprague Dawley rats from Charles River (Raleigh, NC)."
comments.rationale:
Authors investigate the cellular localization of the actin-binding protein cortactin in rat brain using confocal imaging and immuno EM. Confocal imaging revealed that cortactin immunoreactivity is localized apposed to the presynaptic protein synaptophysin and Vglut, which suggests its presence in the postsynaptic compartment of excitatory synapses. Co-staining with a lipophilic dye that labels plasma membrane revealed the accumulation of cortactin in dendritic spines. Electron microscopy with immunoperoxidase labeling of cortactin revealed staining in dendrites which was denser within dendritic spines below PSDs, confirming the localization of cortactin within spines. In order to gain insight into the precise location of the protein, immunogold EM was performed. In agreement with previous results, immunogold labeling was prominent in spines, usually associated with electron-dense filaments, which suggests interaction with cytoskeleton. Analysis of the distribution of the immunogold particles within the spines revealed that these are localized 100-150nm away from the synapse, in the spine core.

11/8/2017 Pim
- Based on prior knowledge of Cortactin and the statement "... usually associated with electron-dense filaments..." I allow annotation to the term  'postsynaptic actin cytoskeleton (GO:0098871)' without an IC construct.

comments.species:
For figure 2 and 4 and 5, KO data: '...Hippocampal neurons from E17 mice or E18 Sprague-Dawley rats were plated...'
For the overexpression construct in figure 2, 4, and 5: no available information of the species of the cDNA.
comments.rationale:
AlphaN-catenin is an actin interactor. The paper examines the effect of alphaN-catenin deletion on the postsynaptic dynamics of the actin cytoskeleton in spines.

Figure 2 examines the rate of spin mobility, as estimated using time-lapse imaging in cultured mouse neurons transfected with an EGFP-tagged actin. In the alphaN-catenin knockout, the change in spine length is higher (indicating higher mobility), and in the alphaN-catenin over-expressing neurons the rate is lower (Quantified in Figure 2e,f).

Figure 4: monitoring of spines using time-lapse imaging in cultured mouse neurons transfected with an EGFP-tagged actin. Identical dendrites were analyzed over a period of 10 days. The rate of unchanged spines was highest in alphaN-catenin overexpressing neurons and lowest in the KO neurons. Conversely, the rate of disappearing spines was highest in KO neurons and lowest in the over-expressing neurons.

Figure 5 shows that only the deletion of the actin-binding domain of alphaN-catenin (Fig. 5a, 1-870)  leads to an increase in the number of spines (Fig. 5c) as seen for the over expression of the WT construct, indicating that the actin-binding site is mediating the effect of alphaN-catenin on the stability of spines.

Taken together, these data suggest that the lack of-, or the over expression of alphaN-caenin affects the spin stability through its interaction with the actin cytoskeleton.

comments.species: 'To generate mice lacking β-catenin in excitatory neurons in the hippocampus, mice with two loxP-flanked β-catenin alleles (β-catenin flox/flox) were crossed with mice in which CamKII regulatory elements control cre recombinase expression (CamKcre).'
comments.rationale:
The paper makes use of a conditionally-floxed beta-catenin CKO mouse line. The conditional deletion is achieved via a CaMKII-cre transgenic allele (this results in a deletion at around P18).
Figure 2: electron microscopy of stratum radiatum synapses shows:
- a 25% increase in the number of excitatory, spine synapses (2A,B,D) in the CKO.
- a 3-fold increase in perforated synapses (2C,E) in the CKO.
- a 40% reduction in the undocked pool of vesicles per synapse (2F) in the CKO.
- The number of docked vesicles located less than one vesicle diameter from
the presynaptic membrane was similar (Figures 2A, 2B, and 2F).
- The reduction in the number of vesicles per synapse in the CKO is not due to redistribution of vesicles over a larger number of synapses. Quantification of the total number of vesicles (in a defined region) shows a 30% reduction in the total number of vesicles.

Taken together these data suggest a presynaptic role of beta-catenin in vesicle clustering at the reserve pool region adjacent to the active zone.

comments.species: Male Wistar rats (6–8 weeks old, 140–160 g, obtained from Harlan Ibérica, Barcelona, Spain) were used
comments.rationale: Treatment with the selective A2A receptor agonist CGS 21680 facilitates the depolarization (20mM K+)-dependent release of radiolabelled glutamate from isolated synaptosomes (Fig 1). The facilitatory effect was blocked by the selective A2A receptor antagonist SCH 5861, but not significantly by the A1 receptor antagonist DPCPX (Fig. 1). Subcellular fractionation of synaptosomes demonstrates the presence of A2A in presynaptic membranes (as well as predominately in postsynaptic membranes; Fig.3) and ICC using an antibody directed against A2A demonstrates a co-localization of A2A and synaptophysin and vGluT1 and 2 immunoreactivity (Fig.4). These data indicate a presynaptic function of A2A receptors in facilitating neurotransmitter release upon binding of adenosine.

comments.species:
From M&M:
-Male Wistar rats were used for preparation of tissue extracts, subcellular fractionation of brain and im- munofluorescence staining of cryosections.
-The labeled DNA probe was a double- stranded oligonucleotide containing the NF-KB binding motif from the mouse K light chain enhancer (Promega).
comments.rationale: Authors use electrophoretic mobility shift assays (EMSAs) to detect the presence of kB-DNA-binding activities in the rat brain and rat synaptosomal preparations. They used a 32P-oligonucleoutide containing an NF-kB binding motif which was incubated with cell extracts and subjected to electrophoresis after the binding reaction to detect changes in motility. kB-binding activity was found in synaptosomal fractions with, but also without though less, treatment with DOC, which reveals latent kB-binding activities sequestered by IkB proteins. Previously, authors have described that p65/RelA complexes are responsible for kB-binding activities found in rat brain since incubation the IkB protein MAD3, which inhibits DNA-binding complexes containing p65 abolished the binding activities. The same effect was found when they used an antibody against the N terminus of p65, which also prevented DOC-activated complexes.

comments.species: "Sequences encoding full-length SynCAM 2 (splice product 2) (Biederer, 2006), SynCAM 3 (splice product 2), and SynCAM 4 were amplified from a mousebrain cDNA library prepared at 9–11 weeks of age (Clontech #639400)."
comments.rationale:
The adhesive interactions of the synaptic adhesion molecule SynCAM 1 were mapped in this study. 
The homophilic binding of SynCAM 1 extracellular domains in trans is shown in Fig. 5, using a bead aggregation assay and a cell-cell contact analysis. 
Testing heterophilic interactions, the affinity chromatography results in Fig. 6A show that heterologously expressed SynCAM 1 retains not only SynCAM 1 but also SynCAM 2 from adult rat forebrain extracts. Beads coated with SynCAMs 2 and 3 each retain SynCAM 1 from forebrain extracts. Heterophilic interactions of SynCAM 1 and SynCAM 2 are further supported by the analysis of cell-cell contact assembly in Fig. 6B. All interactions are Ca2+ independent.

comments.species: From materials and methods, "Hippocampal CA3–CA1 regions were dissected from 1- to 3-d-old Sprague Dawley rats..."
comments.rationale:
The authors use shRNA to knockdown (KD) AP-2 mu2 in cultured rat hippocampal neurons. In figure 2B they use high intensity stimulation to load the neurons with FM4-64 (which is established to enter in synaptic vesicles (SVs). They wash and then stimulate exocytosis to destain the neurons (as the SVs undergo exocytosis, the FM4-64 dye is release into the culture media and looses fluorescence). Destaining in the KD is ~30% of that in control indicating a large decrease in the pool of recycling SVs. 

In figure 3 they examine the rates of endocytosis of 4 major SV proteins tagged with pHlourin. They stimulate exocytosis and then examine endocytosis of SVs post-stimulation. The rates of all 4 proteins are strongly decreased. 

In figure 4 they examine the rate of endocytosis of vGlutpHlourin during intense stimulation and measure a dramatic reduction.

It is important to note, knockdown of AP-2 mu2 in this manuscript leads to loss of AP-2 alpha. Thus, it is not possible to distinguish between the function of these two proteins as they are obligate heterodimers.

comments.species: 'Twelve adult male Sprague-Dawley rats (Harlan Sprague Dawley Inc., Indianapolis, IN, USA; 250–270g) housed two to three to a cage (20°C, 12-h light, 12-h dark cycle lights on 0700) were used in this study.'
comments.rationale:
The paper uses immunogold-silver detection to study the subcellular localization of WLS in noradrenergic locus coeruleus neurons. Wls is a multi-pass transmembrane glycoprotein essential for Wnt cell signaling.

Figure 3 shows silver deposits in somatodendritic processes apposing a presynaptic, vesicle-filled terminal. Some deposits are associated with the plasma membrane. Since that a clear association with sub cellular organelles is not seen or mentioned, and the membrane association is not directly at the postsynaptic membrane, one can (only) use the above-mentioned data to demonstrate a post-synaptic localization of Wls.

comments.species:
Fluoresence immunocytochemistry analysis of CNAgamma was  performed on cultured rat hippocampal neurons.
For electron microscopy, vibratome sections from mouse hippocampi were used incubated with an anti-mouse CNA gamma antibody.
For antisera generation, human and mouse CNA gamma peptides were used.  
-Labeling of cultured rat hippocampal neurons was done with antibodies against rat CNA gamma (affinity purified antisera).
comments.rationale: Authors generated a specific antibody against calcineurin gamma which they used for studying the cellular localization of the protein. Coimmunostaining of primary hippocampal neurons reveals colocalization of CNA gamma with the glutamatergic presynaptic marker VGlut, which suggest the presence of CNA gamma in glutamatergic synapses. Subsequent pre-embedding immunoEM performed in hippocampal sections revealed CNA gamma immunoreactivity in the presynaptic compartment, in the vicinity of synaptic vesicles. This was supported by post-embedding immunogold EM, which also revealed the presence of the protein in the cytosol of the presynaptic compartment.

comments.species: "Rat hippocampal neurons were cotransfected with a Ppp3cc-specific shRNA and the vGlut1- pHluorin construct." "Oligonucleotides of the rat Ppp3cc cDNA target sequence (CGGCTAACTTTGA- AGGAAGTA, Invitrogen) were annealed and ligated into pSUPER"
comments.rationale: Authors use a sh-RNA to knockdown CNA gamma in rat primary hippocampal neurons  and monitor dynamics of the synaptic vesicle cycle of excitatory synapses using Vglut1-pHluorin. Analysis of the Vglut1-pHluorin responses after 10Hz 100 action potential stimulation revealed a mild, non significant effect of CNA gamma knockdown in synaptic vesicle exocytosis. Analysis of endocytosis kinetics, however, revealed a significant decrease of the time constant of fluorescence recovery, tau, which was rescued by over expression of a shRNA resistant CNA gamma vector. Analysis of the reacidification kinetics discarded an impairment of vesicle reacidification and supported the role of CNA gamma in synaptic vesicle endocytosis. This role seems specific of the gamma isoform and not beta or alpha, since over expression of these did not rescue the endocytosis phenotype, and over expression of the gamma isoform carrying a point mutation in the catalytic domain which inactivates calcineurin could also not rescue the phenotype.
