comments.species: 'Fly Strains: Flies were reared in standard Drosophila media at 25°C unless otherwise stated. (See Suppl. Materials for fly strains.) RNAi crosses and controls were performed at 29°C. The wgts flies were tested at the restrictive temperature (25°C).'
comments.rationale:
The paper uses pre-embedding immunogold-Silver detection to study the subcellular localization of WLS in the fly neuromuscular junction. Wls is a multi-pass transmembrane glycoprotein essential for Wnt cell signaling.

Figure 5F, 5J shows Wls/Evi at the presynaptic membrane (presynaptic compartment labelled in pink). 
Fig. 5G shows Wls/Evi at large presynaptic multi-membrane structures.

comments.species: 'Fly Strains: Flies were reared in standard Drosophila media at 25°C unless otherwise stated. (See Suppl. Materials for fly strains.) RNAi crosses and controls were performed at 29°C. The wgts flies were tested at the restrictive temperature (25°C).'
comments.rationale:
Wls is a multi-pass transmembrane glycoprotein essential for Wnt cell signaling. The paper shows that Wls/Evi is required for the transport and/or secretion of Wg  (the Wnt-1 homolog Wingless) in presynaptic terminals of the neuromuscular junction, and that Wls/Evi can cross from the pre- to the postsynaptic compartments of the synapse .

Figure1A, C, E makes use of a Wls/Evi knockout to show that the localization of the signaling molecule Wg (the Wnt-1 homolog Wingless). HRP signal is used to mark the presynaptic compartment, so that the localization of Wg in both the pre- and postsynaptic compartments can be made, and quantification is presented in 
figure 1E. The Wls knockout leads to a reduction in the Wg signal in both pre- and postsynaptic compartments.
Figure 1B shows a rescue experiment where Wls/Evi is expressed on the knockout background, but only at the presynaptic neurons. This leads to a rescue of the Wg signal in both presynaptic neuron and postsynaptic muscle (quantification in 1E). The postsynaptic expression of Wls/Evi in the muscle (1D) does not lead to rescue.

Figure 5 shows using electron microscopy that Wls/Ewi can move between the pre- and post-synaptic compartments. GFP-tagged Wls/Evi was expressed in motorneurons. Anti-GFP labelling shows that the GFP signal can be found also at the postsynaptic muscle (5D). Expression of GFP-tagged Wls/Evi in the presynaptic neurons on the KO background had a similar effect: GFP-Wls/Evi could be found not only in the neurons but also at the postsynaptic muscle and at the synaptic cleft (5I, J, K).

Taken together, the paper shows that Wls/Evi is important for the localization or secretion of the signaling molecule Wg, and that Wls/Evi is able to move across the synaptic cleft.

3/2/2017 Pim
- The method of Evi/Wntless mediating signals from pre- to post-synapse is different from what I initially thought based on this description. Please see Fig.7 for a model. In short, Evi is a protein in the pre and post secrotory pathway that mediates carrying the intra vesicular Wnt signal across the synapse in exosome-like vesicles.

comments.species: For the fractionation of PSD, rat brain homogenates were produced and the crude synaptosomes P2 was isolated as described
comments.rationale:
The paper demonstrates that an abundant signal for catenin delta can be detected in purified PSD fractions from rat brain using WB (Fig 1b).

Figure 3 shows that delta-Catenin interacts with glutamate receptor complexes in brain. A WB signal for delta-Catenin can be found in IP fractions of PSD95, MgluR1alpha and NR2A (3A). The receptors can be detected in a delta-catenin IP sample (3B-D).

21/8/2017 Pim
- Via PMID:9971746 the annotated gene was traced to rat CTNND2 (compared peptide sequences shown in Fig.1 PEPAPPPPPPP and KKKKKKK)

comments.species: M&M: "Adult female Wistar rats, 10 weeks old, were used for this study. "
comments.rationale:
Much signal was detected outside synapses ("unclassified processes" FIg1B). Fig1 C shows presynaptic DAB labeling of Flotilin-1 in parietal cortex. Of 50 Flot1 positive synapses, 80% of the signals was on the presynaptic side, the remainder on the postsynaptic side (main text p85). This is in line with qualitative observations in the visual cortex of rats (PMID 25732136, Fig6 see additional reference).

8/7/2017 Pim
- Authors note: "In synapses, one or two patchy areas appeared on perisynaptic membranes, axon terminals, but never on presynaptic active zones or postsynaptic densities (Fig. 1C), although about half of the synapses showed no labeling"

comments.species: At the calyx of Held synapse in brainstem slices of 5- to 7-day-old (P5-7) rats
comments.rationale:
Activation of the G-protein coupled adenosine A1 receptor by adenosine causes an inhibition of neurotransmitter release by modulating presynaptic calcium currents. 
Principal cells in the MNTB in acute brainstem slices were analyzed by whole cell patch clamp electrophysiology and presynaptic action potentials were evoked by fiber stimulation. Bath application of adenosine caused an attenuation of EPSCs and the effect could be rescued by the application of the adenosine A1 receptor antagonist CPT (Fig.1) indicating that activation of A1 receptors results in an inhibition of neurotransmitter release. Whole-cell voltage-clamp recordings from presynaptic calyx of Held terminals in response to a strong depolarization pulse revealed that bath application of adenosine resulted in an inhibition of presynaptic calcium currents (Fig.4), indicating a clear presynaptic effect for A1 receptors in the calyx of Held synapse.

comments.species: Under deep anesthesia with diethyl ether, C57BL/6N male mice at postnatal 10–12 weeks transcardially fixed with 4% paraformaldehyde
comments.rationale:
SynArfGEF/BRAG3/IQSEC3 localizes to postsynaptic specializations of symmetrical, inhibitory synapses. Immunohistochemical analysis of the mouse forebrain, cerebellum, and spinal cord revealed that IQSEC3 colocalizes with gephrin, a component of inhibitory postsynaptic specializations (Fig. 1e-g, o-q; s-u; Fig.4b-d, k-n), but not with PSD-95, a component of the postsynaptic density of asymmetric, excitatory synapses (Fig.1h-i). Further, IQSEC3 immunoreactivity colocalizes with the staining pattern of GABAARs (Fig.4e-g) and GlyRs (Fig.4k-n), but not of GluA2Rs (Fig.h-j). Pre-embedding immuno-EM confirmed the presence of IQSEC3-immunoreactivity at postsynaptic specializations of symmetrical synapses (Fig.5).

Antibodies (rabbit and guinea pig) were generated in this study using a GST-IQSEC3 fusion protein and specificity was tested by Western Blot (Fig.2) and for IHC by pre-absorption of the antigen (Fig.3b).

comments.species: Expression plasmids for fragments of rat IQSEC3 (GenBankTM accession number, NM_207617) were prepared by amplifying...
comments.rationale:
SynArfGEF/BRAG3/IQSEC3 is a synaptic guanine nucleotide exchange factor present in inhibitory postsynapses with the capability to activate Arf6. IQSEC3 interacts with gephrin at inhibitory synapses (Fig. 1, 2, 4) and overexpression and knock-down experiments in cultured neurons indicate that IQSEC3 is involved in the regulation of synapse development and this activity is dependent on the Arf-GEF activity of IQSEC3 (Fig. 5, 8,).

The referenced paper demonstrates that IQSEC3 activates Arf6 and localizes to inhibitory synapses.

5/7/2017 Pim
- SynArfGEF/BRAG3/IQSEC3 over-expression is shown to affect the number of DIV10 neuron synapses (Fig.5). Interaction of SynArfGEF/BRAG3/IQSEC3 with the postsynaptic marker protein Gephyrin is needed for this effect (Fig.7). This effect does rely on the ArfGEF activity of SynArfGEF/BRAG3/IQSEC3 (Fig.8). Fig.10 shows effect shRNA SynArfGEF/BRAG3/IQSEC3 KD on postsynaptic specialization size. Together this can be used to justify the term:

"positive regulation of ARF protein signal transduction (GO:0032014)"
occurs_in "postsynapse (GO:0098794)"
part_of "synapse organization (GO:0050808)"

comments.species: Under deep anesthesia with diethyl ether, adult C57BL/6 mice were perfused with 50 ml of 4% paraformaldehyde...
comments.rationale:
IQ-ArfGEF/BRAG1/IQSEC2 is present in the synaptic PSD fraction (Fig.6E) and interacts with PSD-95 (Fig. 6B, C, F) in in vitro-experiments and in homogenates from adult mouse forebrains. IQSEC2 immunoreactivity co-localizes with the labelling of PSD-95, a component of the postsynaptic density of asymmetric, excitatory synapses, but not with that of GABAARbeta1, indicating a specific localization of IQSEC2 to excitatory synapses (Fig.7, 8). Postembedding-immunogold labelling for electron microscopy confirms the presence of IQSEC2 at  postsynaptic densities at asymmetrical synapses (Fig. 9).

Rabbit antibodies were generated in this study using GST and MBP fusion proteins of the C-terminal region (116 aas) of IQSEC2. The specificity of the antibody was tested by Western Blot (Fig 6D) and using antibody, pre-absorved with the antigen, for IHC (data not shown).

comments.species: Ten mice were used for light immunohistochemical analysis and six for immunoelectron microscopic observation.
comments.rationale: IQ-ArfGEF/BRAG1/IQSEC2 is present in retinal photoreceptor terminals and localizes to synaptic ribbons, which are electron-dense structures that tether synaptic vesicles in these synapses in proximity to release sites. Immunohistochemical analysis demonstrates co-localization of immunoreactivity for RIBEYE (the structural component of synaptic ribbons) and bassoon, which is present at the ribbon base, but not PSD-95 (Fig. 2), indicating a presynaptic localization of IQSEC2 in this synapse type. The presence of immunoreactivity at synaptic ribbons at photoreceptor terminals was confirmed by pre-embedding immunoperoxidase and -gold labelling (Fig. 3).

comments.rationale: The data shows the selective association of APP with the sub-fraction derived from brain synaptosomes that harbours plasmamembrane associated vesicles. These fractions when immuno-isolated with a synaptic vesicle antibody elute active zone associated proteins more readily. This synaptic enrichment is reinforced by classic sub-fractionations.

comments.rationale:
IQ-ArfGEF/BRAG1/IQSEC2 is a guanine nucleotide exchange factor present in postsynaptic densities of glutamatergic synapses.

Overexpression of wildtype BRAG1 in CA1 pyramidal cells in rat hippocampal organotypic slice cultures causes an increase in AMPA receptor mediated responses (Fig.1c, d). 

Overexpression of a dominant-negative mutant BRAG1-E849K, which lacks Arf-GEF enzymatic activity, still causes an increase in AMPA receptor mediated responses (Fig. 1b), indicating that the enhancement in AMPA receptor responses is unrelated to the enzymatic activity of BRAG1, but rather depends on its C-terminal interactions with PSD-95 (Fig.2). 

Knock-down (KD) of BRAG1 using different siRNA constructs causes a reduction in AMPA receptor mediated responses (Fig.7a-e) that can be rescued by expression of wildtype BRAG1 (Fig.7f). BRAG1 overexpression increases surface expression levels of GluA2 (Fig. 6), but overexpression or KD of BRAG1 has no effect on LTP generation at the CA3-CA1 SC synapse (Fig.9). However, KD of BRAG1 affects LTD indicating that removal of AMPA receptors is affected in the absence of BRAG1 and this effect depends on the enzymatic Arf-GEF activity of BRAG1 (Fig.10).

In summary, these data indicate that BRAG1 modulates the expression levels of AMPA receptors at postsynapses.

comments.species: Under deep anesthesia with pentobarbital, C57BL/6 mice were decapitated and the eyes were quickly enucleated.
comments.rationale:
GEP100/BRAG2/IQSEC1 localizes to glutamatergic postsynaptic specializations in the inner plexiform layer of the mouse retina. Immunohistochemical analysis demonstrated a strong co-localization of the immunoreactivity of BRAG2 with PSD-95 (Fig. 5A-E) and AMPA receptors (Fig. 5K-O), but not with gephrin, a marker of inhibitory postsynapses (Fig. 5F-J). The presence of BRAG2 at excitatory postsynapses was confirmed by pre-embedding immuno EM, showing that BRAG2 localizes to AMPA-containing postsynaptic processes receiving input from glutamatergic bipolar ribbon synapses in the IPL (Fig. 7).

The guinea pig antibody against BRAG2 was generated in the study and tested for its specificity by Western Blot and by ICC after expression of the protein in COS-7 cells (Fig. 1). The antibody detects three BRAG2 isoforms or slice variants, but exhibits no cross-reactivity with BRAG1 or -3.

comments.species: Lentiviral stock was injected into the hippocampus of 3-week-old mice (Dittgen et al., 2004).
comments.rationale:
GEP100/BRAG2/IQSEC1 is a guanine nucleotide exchange factor for Arf6 at excitatory postsynapses. BRAG2 interacts with AMPA receptors (Fig. 1) and can be co-immunoprecipitated with GluA2 from neurons (Fig. 1E). Subcellular fractionation demonstrates an enrichment of BRAG2 in the PSD fractions, similarly to PSD-95 (Fig. 2B, C). BRAG2 mediated activation of Arf6 is necessary for the internalization of AMPA receptors during chemical (mGluR-mediated; Fig.6, 7) and electrical (NMDAR-mediated; Fig.8) LTD at Schaffer Collateral CA3-CA1 synapses in acute hippocampal brain slices. Knock-down using BRAG2-RNAi and Knock-out (KO) using Cre-infected conditional BRAG2 KO mice prevents the expression of LTD. 
In summary, BRAG2 is essential for the expression of hippocampal LTD, which is mediated by the endocytosis of AMPA receptors. 

The specificity of the BRAG2 antibody was demonstrated by Western Blot using KD and KO controls (Fig. S3 and S4).

comments.rationale: In this study authors generated antisera against calcineurin A alpha by immunizing a rabbit and used it to detect calcineurin A alpha in different subcellular fractions prepared from rat brain. Though data showing the relative amounts of calcineurin A alpha in the different fractions is only presented in a table format and blots are not shown, authors claim that Calcineurin A alpha is enriched in the P2C fraction containing synaptosomes, and when this fraction was lysed, 80% of the protein was recovered in the soluble fraction, which suggest that calcineurin A alpha is most abundant in the synaptic cytosol.

homogenates from various regions of the rat brain and in aliquots of subcellular fractions, male Wistar rats (weighing 150-200 g) were decapitated, and brains were quickly removed."

The antisera was prepared using cDNA fragments containing amino acids 179-525 or 406-525 of the calcineurin A beta sequence described in Kuno et al., 1989.
comments.rationale: In this study authors generated antisera against different calcineurin A isoforms (alpha and beta) by immunizing rabbits with different peptides and used them to study the localization of both isoforms in different subcellular fractions prepared from rat brain. Though data showing the relative amounts of each protein in the different fractions is only presented in a table format and blots are not shown, authors claim that calcineurin A beta, similar to calcineurin A alpha, is enriched in the P2C fraction containing synaptosomes, and when this fraction was lysed, 80% of the protein was recovered in the soluble fraction, which suggest that calcineurin A alpha and beta are most abundant in the synaptic cytosol.

comments.rationale: This paper addresses the role of Rho GTPases in spine morphology changes upon stimulation. The stimulation is provided by glutamate uncaging and the assay is validated in Fig 1. Fig 3 addresses how GTPases RhoA and CDC42 are involved in the postsynaptic volume change upon glutamate uncaging. The data shows that CDC42 knockdown affects the sustained response selectively, and this can can be rescued by expression of shRNA resistant CDC42 (Fig 3E, F, I and J). Similar results are obtain by the acute expression of the CDC42-binding domain of WASP (Fig3G) that functions as a CDC42 inhibitor.

comments.species: Both mice and rats are used. "Transverse hippocampal slices (300 microns) were obtained from Sprague-Dawley rats (P16-30) or C57BL6J mice."; "CB1+/+, CB1+/- and CB1−/− mice were of both genders and varied in age from 6 weeks to 8 months"
comments.rationale:
Figure 1C,D: Depolarization of CA1 postsynaptic pyramidal neurons mobilizes endocannabinoids, which retrogradely activate presynaptic CB1 receptors, transiently decreasing GABAergic inhibitory neurotransmission (depolarization-induced suppression of inhibition or DSI) or glutamatergic excitatory neurotransmission (depolarization-induced suppression of excitation or DSE). DSI is lost in CB1 knockout mice (Figure 1C,D). Additionally, DSE is lost in CB1 knockout mice (Figure 8A of Ohno-Shosaku, T. et al (2002) J Neurosci, 22(10), 3864-3872). 

Figure 3: In addition, evidence is shown that presynaptic N-Type Ca2+ channels are required for endocannabinoid signaling. DSI is occluded by a specific antagonist of N-type channels, ω-conotoxin GVIA, indicating a presynaptic requirement for N-type calcium channels in the regulation of GABAergic transmission by cannabinoids. Conversely, blocking P/Q-type channels results in increased DSI (removes a component of GABA release that is insensitive to DSI and therefore modulation of N-type calcium channels by cannabinoids is now very relevant).

comments.species:
The cDNA source is not described in this paper, but rather in a previous paper: 'A full length δ-catenin cDNAwas subcloned into pEGFP behind the CMV promoter (BD Biosciences) as described previously (Lu et al., 1999).'

From Lu et al., 1999: 'In the region of the mouse  -catenin start codon (Paffenholz and Franke, 1997), a homologous human EST of 150 base pairs is in the database (GenBank accession number AA670399). This short sequence was used to design a sense primer which, together with an antisense primer from the previously known human sequence (Paffenholz and Franke, 1997; Zhou et al., 1997), was used to amplify the human 5  cDNA sequence by reverse transcriptase PCR.'
comments.rationale:
The paper studies the effect of the over expression of delta-Catenin on AMPA receptor surface expression.

Figure 1D: 
A1-A4 show the effect of over expression of the WT delta-catenin in organotipic slices: the AMPA to NMDA ratio increases dramatically, possibly indicating an increase in the fraction of AMPA receptors at the membrane.
B1-B4: when a mutant delta-Catenin is expressed where the c-terminal PDZ domain is deleted, the effect is not seen.

Figure 2 shows that when data-catenin, GRIP and GluR2 are expressed in COS7 cells, the fraction of membrane GluR2 is higher (as assessed by a biotinilation assay, lanes labelled 'B').

Figure 3 uses immunoflorescence to show that the overexpression of delta-catenin in cultured hippocampal neurons increases the expression of GluR2 (Figure 3A), and GRIP (Fig. 3B) in spines, but not of NMDA receptors (Figure 3C).

Taken together the data suggests that delta-catenin over-expression may increase the surface fraction of GluR2 via its interaction with GRIP. The electrophysiology data would argue that at lease a fraction of the inserted AMPA receptors are synaptic.

comments.rationale: Pre-embedding immunogold electron microscopy was performed using a commercial antibody directed against Alpha1 adrenergic receptors (aa339-349, rb, polyclonal). Pre-absorption of the antibody with the A1 peptide eliminated the immunolabelling (data not shown, but mentioned in the text). A1 adrenergic receptors (A1ARs) were localized primarily pre-synaptically in unmyelinated axons and axon terminals (Fig. 3a) in the nucleus accumbens (NAc), ventral tegmental area (VTA) and the prefrontal cortex (PFC). ~60% of axonal A1ARs were associated with the plasma membrane (Fig. 3b). The majority of the axonal A1ARs were found extrasynaptically (not associated with the active zone or the peri-active zone; Fig. 3c). Co-labelling with different markers revealed that A1ARs are localized to different types of neurons (TH - dopaminergic, vGluT1/2 - glutamatergic, GABA - Gabaergic; Fig. 4).

comments.species:
From M&M:
-Hippocampal organotypic slices were prepared from 8-day-old Wistar rats.
-shRNAs against rat STAT3 were synthesized.
comments.rationale: Authors show that induction of NMDAR-LTD by low-frequency stimulation (900stimuli at 1Hz) at CA1 synapses requires STAT3.  To test this, they used pharmacological blockade of STAT3 by application of two different compounds, Stattic and STA-21, and a sh-RNA-mediated downregulation of STAT3 protein levels. In both scenarios, NMDAR-LTD induction is prevented, which suggests the involvement of STAT3 in NMDAR-LTD.

comments.rationale: This paper identities the cDNA from the chick alpha Cadherin gene cluster. It utilizes predicted amino acids from the constant cytoplasmic domain to immuno-label chick ciliary ganglia. The show apposition to post synaptic nicotinic receptors and co-labelling with presynaptic markers. Subsequent labelling and co-staining of chick iris muscle and axons support the notion of axonal and presynaptic targeting not fully extending into the terminal. Evidence lacks resolution to more precisely define synaptic location.

comments.rationale:
Pre-embedding immuno-peroxidase labelling for electron microscopy indicates the presence of Alpha2A Adrenergic receptor (Alpha2A-AR) immunoreactivity in a large percentage of axons and axon terminals in the hippocampus (Fig. 5, 8, 9). The majority of the labelled synapses were asymmetric (Fig. 5B, E), but presynaptic immunoreactivity was also found in some symmetric terminals that were contacting somata or dendritic shafts (for example Fig. 5A).  Alpha2A-AR immunoreactivity was found near the presynaptic membrane (Fig. 5A,D), but the peroxidase reaction product was also present throughout the presynaptic terminal associated with synaptic vesicles.

Preabsorption of the antibody with the peptide completely abolishes immunostaining (Fig. 1C).

Alpha2C-AR immunoreactivity was often associated with plasma membrane regions apposed to astrocytes or presynaptic terminals, and frequently adjacent to postsynaptic densities (Fig. 2B, 3B). However, immunoreactivity was also found at a distance from the PSD at the membrane as well as in the cytoplasm of dendrites and endomembranes.

comments.species: Rat tissue is largely used as explicitly stated in Methods: Male Wistar rats (300-350g) but figures mention mouse hippocampal and cerebellar sections (e.g. figure 8). Citation to previous papers in the immunoisolation section of materials and methods would suggest that immuno-isolation of synaptic vesicles used rat as starting material.
comments.rationale: Quantitative proteomic comparisons indicates an enrichment of MAL2 in synaptic vesicles that harbour vGlut-1 and would store glutamate. An antibody that shows specificity for MAL-2 based on peptide antigen competition is used. Western blotting of synaptic subcellular fractions, immunofluoresence co-localization with synaptic vesicle markers, immunogold electron labelling of purified synaptic vesicles and within intact tissue all evidence MAL-2 as a bona-fide synaptic vesicle membrane protein.

comments.species:
The papers clones the rat cDNA for the SGT-alpha and performs the protein interactions with Rat cDNA. There are several protein interaction and in vitro assays based on recombinant proteins expressed form Rat cDNA. However the best evidence for a direct synaptic localization directing function is from CSP-alpha knock out tissue.
Evidence from materials and methods: e.g. Full length DNAs for rat CSP1 and Hsc70; Yeast strain L40.......was sequentially transfected with bait..........and a rat brain cDNA library.
comments.rationale: The paper describes that SGT-alpha binds to the synaptic vesicle protein CSP alpha. This is evidenced by robust yeast two hybrid data and recombinant protein binding studies. CSP-alpha is shown to simultaneously bind SGT-alpha and its other Hsc70 binding partner, thus forming a trimeric complex. In vitro studies show that the trimeric complex synergizes the ATPase and refolding activity of Hsc70. This is based on measurements of the ATPase activity of the trimeric complex and the refolding of a model substrate firefly luciferase. Comparing these activities imparted by individual or pairwise mixes of the components highlights the synergistic activity of the trimeric complex. The important evidence in terms of the synaptic localization is that the pool of the largely cytoplasmic SGT-alpha that is bound to synaptic vesicles is lost when these organelles are made from CSP alpha knockout mouse. These observations are critically dependent on a SGT-alpha antibody whose specificity is defined by a lack of immunoreactivity in pre-immune sera.

comments.species:
β1AR-CT (the carboxyl-terminal 99 amino acids of the human β1AR) and β2AR-CT (the carboxyl-terminal 86 amino acids of the human β2AR) were amplified

comments.rationale: In a yeast-2-hybrid screen, beta1-adrenergic receptors (ARs) were found as binding partners of PSD-95, a major component of postsynaptic density (Fig. 1). The interaction was validated by co-immunoprecipitation assays using overexpression in non-neuronal cells (Fig. 2). Only beta1-ARs, but not beta2-ARs interact with PSD-95 (Fig. 2B). No co-IP from brain homogenate was performed/shown.

comments.species: C57b6 mice (Jackson) of either sex, aged 7–18 weeks, were used.
comments.rationale:
Beta1-Adrenergic receptors (ARs) are G-Protein coupled receptors that bind epinephrine and norepinephrine. In CA3-CA1 Schaffer collateral synapses of the hippocampus, beta1-ARs are selectively involved in the generation of late-LTP in a PKA-dependant manner and via activation of ERK. 

To induce robust LTP, a protocol was chosen in which prolonged (3min) 5Hz stimulation is paired with beta-AR activation by application of 1 µM Iso (Fig. 2A). The induction of this form of LTP is dependent on beta1-AR activation since it is abolished in beta1-KO and beta1/beta2-DKO mice (Fig.2C), but not in beta2-KO mice (Fig. 2D). Basal synaptic transmission in beta1-KO mice is normal (Fig. 2E) indicating a selective effect during LTP generation. This form of LTP is further dependent on PKA since LTP is reduced in the presence of the PKA-inhibitor KT5720 (Fig. 3A) and depends on activation of ERK, since inhibition of ERK by the use of MEK inhibitors (e.g. U0126; Fig. 3B) also reduces LTP. 

MEK inhibitors did not change fEPSP slopes (Fig. 4D), indicating that beta-AR activation by Iso does not transiently enhance presynaptic synaptic transmission. In contrast, during the 5 Hz stimulation, postsynaptic CA1 neurons are known to generate AP firing patterns and application of Iso during the tetanus increases the number of postsynaptic spikes (Fig. 5A, B, E). 

These findings indicate that beta1-AR activation enhances LTP generation via postsynaptic signaling pathways that enhance neuronal excitability.

17/8/2017 Pim
-  The effect on "neuronal excitability" is translated into the term 'regulation of postsynaptic membrane potential'.

comments.species:
Information regarding used species is missing also in referenced papers. The only available information in this paper is the following: 
"To identify proteins that regulate the endocytic sorting of GABAARs, we carried out a Y2H screen of a rat hippocampal library (15, 16), with a bait encoding the intracellular domain of the GABAAR 1 subunit, and identified several interacting clones that en- coded the central domain of rat HAP1 (residues 220–520). " 
"Interaction of full-length rat HAP1 with the intracellular domains of GABAAR subunits expressed as GST fusion proteins was also tested."

11/8/2017
- Authors state "Interaction of full-length rat HAP1 with the intracellular domains of GABAAR subunits expressed as GST fusion proteins was also tested." We assume that the same rat cDNA was used for overexpression.
comments.rationale: Authors shows that HAP1 directly interacts with GABAA receptors and can modulate the their fate. HAP1a overexpression in cortical cultures leads to a reduction of the degradation of internalized receptors and induces an increase in the recycling of these. Supporting this, amplitudes but not frequencies of mIPSPs were significantly increased upon HAP1a overexpression which suggests a postsynaptic phenotype. Analysis of the inhibitory synaptic currents revealed that this increase in mIPSP amplitude is due to a increase number of channels in the cell surface. In line with this, cell surface biotynilation revealed an increased surface expression of the beta3 subunit of the channel. Beta subunits are essential for the functional expression of these receptors.

comments.species: Wistar rats (12–15 days old) were decapitated
comments.rationale:
Beta2 Adrenergic receptors (ARs) are G-Protein coupled receptors that facilitate synaptic transmission upon activation via a presynaptic mechanism involving adenylate cyclase activation and cAMP generation. 

Application of noradrenaline induces an increase in the mEPSC frequency in dissociated rat ventromedial hypothalamic neurons (Fig. 2A). This increase in mEPS frequency could not be blocked by the alpha1-AR antagonist prozocin or the beta1-AR antagonist atenol (Fig. 3B). However, it could be blocked by the application of the selective beta2-antagonist ICI-188551 and mimicked by application of the beta2-agonist formoterol (Fig. 3A, B, C). Inhibiting adenyl cyclase by the application of SQ22536, did not change the basal mEPSC frequency, but completely abolished NA-induced facilitation of the mEPSC frequency (Fig.4A, B).

comments.species: For this study mice carrying targeted deletions of the genes encoding α2A-, α2B-, or α2C-adrenergic receptors (α2-KO) were used.
comments.rationale:
This paper systematically analyzed the functional consequences of loss of individual and multiple G-Protein coupled alpha2A adrenergic receptor (AR) subtypes using alpha2A-, alpha2B-, and alpha2C-KO mice. 

Receptor autoradiography using radiolabelled RX821002 revealed that alpha2A-and -2C are the two main alpha2 subtypes expressed in the mouse brain. Only the alpha2AC-DKO shows a complete loss of receptor labelling (Fig. 1A). These findings were confirmed by using a radioligand binding assay in purified brain synaptosomes (Fig. 1B). 

In wildtype acute slices of mouse cortex, application of the alpha2-agonist UK14,304 (Fig. 2A, B) or norepinephrine (Fig. 2C) caused an inhibition of radiolabelled norepinephrine release. In slices from alpha2A-KO and -2AC-DKO mice, norepinephrine release is not inhibited (Fig. 2B, C). 

Extensive electrical stimulation induces endogenous norepinephrine release caused an inhibition of radiolabelled norepinephrine in control slices, but not in -2AC-DKO slices, indicating that alpha2-ARs are presynaptic autoreceptors that inhibit synaptic transmission upon activation. 

Further, exogenous application of the alpha2-agonist UK14,304 causes a reduction in radiolabelled dopamine release from basal ganglia from wildtype mice that is only little affected in alpha2AC-DKO mice (Fig. 4B). Also presynaptic glutamate release have been shown to be affected upon activation of presynaptic alpha2-ARs probably due to inhibition of presynaptic N-type Ca2+-channels and activation of inwardly-rectifying K+-channels (see linked papers).

comments.species: For the preparation of hippocampal cultures, hippocampi were carefully dissected from E18 rat embryo brains
comments.rationale: Application of noradrenaline to cultured hippocampal neurons induces a reduction in  the frequency of miniature EPSCs (Fig 4). Application of the selective alpha1-agonist cirazoline also induced a reduction in the mEPSC frequency, but no change in mEPSC amplitude (Fig. 4d, f). These findings indicate that presynaptic G-Protein coupled Alpha1-adrenergic receptors modulate synaptic transmission upon activation.

comments.species: Materials and Methods: "Larvae were dissected in HL-3, fixed for 20 min in 3.7% formaldehyde (5 min in Bouin’s for anti-VGlut) and labeled with antibodies."
comments.rationale:
Rab35 functions together with its GAP, Skywalker, to regulate the sorting of synaptic vesicle membranes through synaptic endosomes via an ESCRT-dependent mechanism. 

In sky mutants, FM1-43 was observed to accumulate in RAB5- and synaptotagmin 1-containing, enlarged presynaptic cisternal-like structures in sky mutants after stimulation of SV exocytosis that is not observed in controls (Fig 2 and 3). Expression of a dominant negative version of Rab35 in sky mutants abolishes these structures and restores FM1-43 to a wildtype like distribution, indicating that Skywalker functions to regulate Rab35-mediate trafficking to these structures. Sorting of synaptic membranes as visualised by using an artificial chimeric version of synaptobrevin as ESCRT cargo revealed that levels of this cargo is significantly reduced as compared to wild type animals (Fig 7). Taken together, the results indicate that Rab35 is responsible for directing a subpopulation of synaptic vesicle proteins and membrane for sorting and/or degradation via synaptic endosomes.

comments.species: All animals were treated according to the guidelines of the Institutional Animal Care and Use Committee (IACUC) of the University of North Carolina. Sprague-Dawley rats (200–300 g, Charles River, Raleigh, NC) were deeply anesthetized with sodium pentobarbital (60 mg/kg, i.p.) and perfused through the heart with 100 ml normal saline, containing 500U heparin sodium at room temperature, followed by either 1 or 4% paraformaldehyde (PF) in phosphate buffer (PB, 0.1 M, pH 7.4). Lumbar segments of spinal cord and L4 DRG were removed and post-fixed for 2 h at 4 8C in the fixative used for perfusion. Blocks of spinal cord were embedded in agar, cut transversely at 70 mm on a Vibratome and stored in PB at 4 8C for up to 2 days before processing. The L4 DRG were cryoprotected in 30% sucrose in PB overnight at 4 8C, embedded in Tissue-Tek O.C.T. compound (Sakura Finetek, Torrance, CA), and sectioned on a cryostat at 15 mm. Every 6th section was thaw-mounted onto pre-cleaned slides and stored at K20 8C.
comments.rationale:
Immuno EM in afferent terminals of rat DRG.

comments.rationale:
In this reference paper, Jahn et al. investigate the distribution of synaptophysin by subcellular fractionation, immunoblotting and immunostaining of coronal sections of rat brain. Additionally, solubilization studies (with Triton X-114 phase separation) and controlled proteolysis of intact and solubilized synaptic vesicles reveal that synaptophysin is an integral vesicular protein.

2/9/2017 Pim
- Based on the known transmembrane topology of the protein, the "integral component of ... membrane" term was chosen.

comments.species:
From M&M: "Subcellular fractions from 6-week-old rats were used for analysis unless otherwise mentioned."

Authors mention "Antiserum specific for MAPK was raised using synthetic peptides as antigens as reported (Gotoh et al., 1991a)" but the peptide sequences are not available (only for ERK1 i the referenced paper). 

Authors also used active MAPK purified from Xenopus oocytes as "Xenopus MAPK can be used to search for ERK2 substrates because the enzyme has extremely high homology in amino acid sequence (97%) to rat ERK2 (Boulton et al., 1991; Gotoh et al.,
1991a)."
comments.rationale:
Authors detect MAPK immunoreactive molecules in PSD fractions prepared from cerebral cortex, hippocampus and cerebellum. Two bands are immunoreactive, which are considered to be ERK1 (43 KDa) and ERK2 (41 KDa). When looking at different subcellular fractions, authors mentioned that ratios of ERK1/ERK2 in the synaptic fractions are different and only ERK2-type MAPK was detected in the PSD fraction. 
Authors used a purified Xenopus MAPK to search for ERK2 substrates in different subcellular fractions and compared it with a see start MAPK (p44). All fractions contained substrates for both types of MAPK  but Xenopus MAPK (ERK2 type) acted more in substrates in the PSD fraction while the ERK1 type acted more in the soluble and P1 fractions, supporting a role of ERK2-type MAPK in the postsynaptic site.

comments.species:
From M&M:
- A random primed cDNA library prepared from seizure-stimulated rat hippocampus and cortex was used for Y2H. 
- Sprague-Dawley rats were used for immunogold EM. 

- From Naisbitt et al., 1999: "Full-length Shank1 and Shank3 cDNAs were obtained by standard hybridization screening of  ZAP II rat cortical and hippocampal cDNA libraries (Stratagene) using digoxigenin-labeled DNA probes from fragments initially isolated in the yeast two-hybrid screen."
comments.rationale: This work was published in the same issue as Naisbitt et al., 1999, which reports the interaction of Shanks with GKAP/PSD95, known to interact with NMDA receptors.  In this work, authors describe the interaction of Shank3 (also Shank1) with Homer, which in turns bind to mGluR1a/5, using Y2H, pull-down assays with GST proteins and coimmunoprecipitation assays from cortex and cerebellum extracts using an antibody against Shank3. Pull-down from heterologous cell expression and also cerebellar and cortex extracts also show that Shank3 can interact directly with mGluR1/5 (and also indirectly with Homer1). Altogether, these publications showing the interaction  with PSD95/GKAP and Homer/mGluR1/5 point to Shanks being a postsynaptic scaffold protein, which also couples NMDAR and mGluR signaling.

The antibody labels axons (Fig4A,B) and axon terminals (Fig4D,E) specifically with little labelling of dendrites or spines. Preimmune serum does not show positive signal (Fig4F).

Information found in Kosako et al., 1994: "We produced an anti-MAPKK antibody by immunizing mice with a bacterially expressed fusion protein between glutathione-S-transferase (GST) and Xenopus MAPKK."
comments.rationale: Authors used MAPKK antisera and detected MAPKK immunoreactivity in PSD fractions prepared from rat cerebral cortex, hippocampus and cerebellum. MAPKK is also present in all analyzed fractions (soluble, synaptosome and synaptic plasma membrane). However,  MAPKK immunoreactivity increased following synaptogenesis (3 weeks after birth) in the synaptosomal and PSD fraction which suggests that MAPKK functions in the synapse.

comments.rationale: The adenosine A2B receptor is a G-protein coupled receptor that is involved in the modulation of synaptic transmission. Application of the A2B agonist BAY 60-6583 did not modify basal synaptic transmission (Fig. 1c), but caused a decrease in the paired-pulse ratio in the Schaffer collateral - commissural pathway in the hippocampus (Fig. 1d). comments.species: Hippocampal slices were obtained from 6- to 8-week- old, male Sprague Dawley rats
comments.rationale:
The adenosine A3 receptor is a G-protein coupled receptor involved in the modulation of synaptic transmission in concert with A1 receptors. Application of the selective A3R agonist Cl-IB-MECA to acute hippocampal slices has no effect on basal synaptic transmission or on LTP generation at Schaffer Collateral synapses (Fig. 1 and 2). Application of adenosine caused an inhibition of evoked inhibitory responses that is mediated by A1 receptors that could be blocked by co-application of the A3R agonist Cl-IB-MECA (Fig. 3c). This effect could be blocked by the A3 antagonist MRS 1191 (Fig. 4b).

17/8/2017 Pim
- The effect on SV exocytosis may be indirect as stated in the discussion: "The present studies have demonstrated that selective activation or antagonism of adenosine A3 receptors alone has no direct effect on synaptic transmission or synaptic plasticity in the CA1 region of rat hippocampus. However, activation of these receptors reduces the sensitivity of presynaptic A1 receptors that inhibit glutamate release in this preparation, whereas responses to other presynaptic modulators at these synapses are unaffected. Based on these results, we hypothesize that an important role of A3receptors in brain may be to regulate the level of sensitivity of A1 receptors, which normally are tonically activated by low concentrations of endogenous adenosine."

comments.rationale:
Immunolabellings of neuromuscular junctions using two different commercial antibodies directed against adenosine A3 receptors were performed. These experiments indicated the presence of A3Rs at NMJ synapses. A3R immunoreactivity did not co-localize with the glial marker S-100, but with the presynaptic membrane marker syntaxin and the muscle membrane marker acetylcholine receptors.

The specificity of the antibodies was assessed by Western blot and pre-incubation of the primary antibody with a control peptide (see material and methods). Further, primary antibody was omitted for IHC to control for unspecific staining by the secondary antibodies.

comments.species: From materials and methods, "Hippocampal CA3–CA1 regions were dissected from 1- to 3-d-old Sprague Dawley rats..."
comments.rationale:
The authors use shRNA to knockdown (KD) AP-2 mu2 in cultured rat hippocampal neurons. In figure 2B they use high intensity stimulation to load the neurons with FM4-64 (which is established to enter in synaptic vesicles (SVs). They wash and then stimulate exocytosis to destain the neurons (as the SVs undergo exocytosis, the FM4-64 dye is release into the culture media and looses fluorescence). Destaining in the KD is ~30% of that in control indicating a large decrease in the pool of recycling SVs. 

In figure 3 they examine the rates of endocytosis of 4 major SV proteins tagged with pHlourin. They stimulate exocytosis and then examine endocytosis of SVs post-stimulation. The rates of all 4 proteins are strongly decreased. 

In figure 4 they examine the rate of endocytosis of vGlutpHlourin during intense stimulation and measure a dramatic reduction.

It is important to note, knockdown of AP-2 mu2 in this manuscript leads to loss of AP-2 alpha. Thus, it is not possible to distinguish between the function of these two proteins as they are obligate heterodimers.

comments.species:
From results, "When we used brain cytosol from mocha mice in our budding assay, SLMV biogenesis from endosomes was reduced to 50% of wild type..."

15/8/2017 Pim
- The endosomal preparations are from PC12 cells (rat)
- The cytoplasmic extracts (that contain the AP3 complex proteins) are from mouse
comments.rationale:
The authors have developed an assay that examines the formation of synaptic like microvesicles from endosomes isolated from PC12 cells. The synaptic vesicle nature of the vesicles is indicated by the fact they sort the synaptic vesicle protein VAMP. The budding of these VAMP positive vesicles is supported by cytosol from wild type mice but is not supported by cytosol from Mocha mice. Mocha mice have a spontaneous mutation in AP-3 delta that renders AP-3 delta null and leads to loss AP-3 complexes.

15/8/2017 Pim
- Literal: "Mocha brain cytosol, **which lacks all AP-3**, cannot provide coat to these vesicles ..." (emphasis added)
- Fig.6 shows partial co-localization of AP-3 delta with neuronal AP-3 complex


--+ Breakdown of paper by Pim

--++ Introduction
Ubiquitous AP-3 subunits:
delta-adaptin                                 --> AP3D1
beta3A-adaptin                             --> AP3B1
mu3A-adaptin                               --> AP3M1
sigma3A or sigma3B-adaptin (?)  --> AP3S1  or AP3S2

Neuronal AP-3 subunits:
beta3B-adaptin                             --> AP3B2
mu3B-adaptin                               --> AP3M2

The adaptin beta, mu and sigma subunits in the AP3 complex are variable. Neurons may use neuron specific variants of beta and/or mu subunits. The AP-3 complex is referred to as the 'neuronal AP-3' complex.

-++ Results
The paper tries to study the involvement of neuron specific AP-3 complexes in SV budding. The role of the beta3B-adaptin and Mu3B-adaptin are assessed in a in vitro budding assay using:
- beta3B-adaptin immunodepleted cytosol
- Cytosol from Mocha mouse brain that lacks neuronal AP3 proteins Mu3B-adaptin resulting in a removal of all AP-3 complex proteins neuronal+ubiquitous
Fig.1: removal of removal of all AP-3 complex proteins (mocha mouse; neuronal+ubiquitous) reduces SV budding with 50%. Immuno-depletion of neuronal+ubiquitous AP-3 from this assay (neuronal+unibuitous) shows the same 50% reduction.
Fig.3: removal of neuronal AP-3 complexes (beta3B-adaptin immunodepleted cytosol) reduces SV budding with 50%. These data strongly suggest that synaptic vesicle budding from endosomes is attributable solely to the neuronal form of the AP-3 complex.
Fig.4: the neuronal AP-3 is not the major form of AP-3 in brain.

Conclusions:
- The neuronal AP-3 complex that contains beta3B-adaptin is shown to be involved in SV budding from endosomes.
- Based on these experiments it is unclear whether the beta3B-adaptin-containing neuronal AP-3 complex also contains the mu3B-adaptin subunit. The mu3B-adaptin KO is used as an apporach that removes all AP-3 subunits.

-++ Possible annotations:
- DIRECT: beta3B-adaptin --> SV budding from endosome
- INFERRED: delta-adaptin --> SV budding from endosome (based on fixed participation in AP-3 complexes)

Problematic annotations:
- sigma3A/sigma3B-adaptin: the experimental show effect of 'sigma3' depletion on SV budding, but do not distinguish between sigma3A/sigma3B-adaptin genes (literal: "pan-ς3 antibodies were prepared against GST fusion protein composed of residues 16–180 of ς3B")
- mu3A/mu3B-adaptin: experiments do not show role of mu3A-adaptin and/or mu3B-adaptin in SV budding.

comments.species: From results, "When we used brain cytosol from mocha mice in our budding assay, SLMV biogenesis from endosomes was reduced to 50% of wild type..."
comments.rationale:
The authors have developed an assay that examines the formation of synaptic like microvesicles from endosomes isolated from PC12 cells. The synaptic vesicle nature of the vesicles is indicated by the fact they sort the synaptic vesicle protein VAMP. The budding of these VAMP positive vesicles is supported by cytosol from wild type mice but is not supported by cytosol from Mocha mice. Mocha mice have a spontaneous mutation in AP-2 delta that renders AP-3 delta null and leads to loss AP-3 complexes.


15/8/2017 Pim
- Literal: "Mocha brain cytosol, **which lacks all AP-3**, cannot provide coat to these vesicles ..." (emphasis added)
- Fig.6 shows partial co-localization of AP-3 delta with neuronal AP-3 complex


--+ Breakdown of paper by Pim

--++ Introduction
Ubiquitous AP-3 subunits:
delta-adaptin                                 --> AP3D1
beta3A-adaptin                             --> AP3B1
mu3A-adaptin                               --> AP3M1
sigma3A or sigma3B-adaptin (?)  --> AP3S1  or AP3S2

Neuronal AP-3 subunits:
beta3B-adaptin                             --> AP3B2
mu3B-adaptin                               --> AP3M2

The adaptin beta, mu and sigma subunits in the AP3 complex are variable. Neurons may use neuron specific variants of beta and/or mu subunits. The AP-3 complex is referred to as the 'neuronal AP-3' complex.

-++ Results
The paper tries to study the involvement of neuron specific AP-3 complexes in SV budding. The role of the beta3B-adaptin and Mu3B-adaptin are assessed in a in vitro budding assay using:
- beta3B-adaptin immunodepleted cytosol
- Cytosol from Mocha mouse brain that lacks neuronal AP3 proteins Mu3B-adaptin resulting in a removal of all AP-3 complex proteins neuronal+ubiquitous
Fig.1: removal of removal of all AP-3 complex proteins (mocha mouse; neuronal+ubiquitous) reduces SV budding with 50%. Immuno-depletion of neuronal+ubiquitous AP-3 from this assay (neuronal+unibuitous) shows the same 50% reduction.
Fig.3: removal of neuronal AP-3 complexes (beta3B-adaptin immunodepleted cytosol) reduces SV budding with 50%. These data strongly suggest that synaptic vesicle budding from endosomes is attributable solely to the neuronal form of the AP-3 complex.
Fig.4: the neuronal AP-3 is not the major form of AP-3 in brain.

Conclusions:
- The neuronal AP-3 complex that contains beta3B-adaptin is shown to be involved in SV budding from endosomes.
- Based on these experiments it is unclear whether the beta3B-adaptin-containing neuronal AP-3 complex also contains the mu3B-adaptin subunit. The mu3B-adaptin KO is used as an apporach that removes all AP-3 subunits.

-++ Possible annotations:
- DIRECT: beta3B-adaptin --> SV budding from endosome
- INFERRED: delta-adaptin --> SV budding from endosome (based on fixed participation in AP-3 complexes)

Problematic annotations:
- sigma3A/sigma3B-adaptin: the experimental show effect of 'sigma3' depletion on SV budding, but do not distinguish between sigma3A/sigma3B-adaptin genes (literal: "pan-ς3 antibodies were prepared against GST fusion protein composed of residues 16–180 of ς3B")
- mu3A/mu3B-adaptin: experiments do not show role of mu3A-adaptin and/or mu3B-adaptin in SV budding.
15/8/2017 Pim
- Literal: "Mocha brain cytosol, **which lacks all AP-3**, cannot provide coat to these vesicles ..." (emphasis added)
- Fig.6 shows partial co-localization of AP-3 delta with neuronal AP-3 complex

comments.species:
Mouse in utero poratin are explicitly mentioned in the methods but the culture method cited in the supplementary indicates rats and methods and figures do not clarify this.

3/2/2017 Pim
 - Overexpressed protein is of mouse species. Literal "cDNA encoding the predicted full-length cadherin-9 gene described in GenBank NM_009869.1 was amplified from a P7 mouse hippocampal cDNA library."
- The species selection here can be either rat (species of neurons and KD protein) or mouse (species of over-expressed protein). I chose the mouse species since this has a reviewed Uniprot (SwissProt) record whereas rat does not.
comments.rationale:
The work shows CDH-9 immunofluorescence in the proximity of synaptic processes. Transfected expression of a tagged version of the CDH-9 indicates a discrete localization of the recombinantly expressed product outside but close to synaptic cluster. Overall evidence suggest targeted expression. Figure 8 highlights shRNA knock down of the CDH-9 proteins exerts a disruption of synaptic structure supporting synaptic function of the protein as assessed by quantitative morphometric EM.

3/7/2017 Pim
- Fig.5C shows the homophilic adhesive property of Cadh9
- Fig.6/7/8 shows that pre-synaptic Cadh9 regulates postsynaptic development and vice versa. In SynGO we have a term "trans-synaptic signaling by trans-synaptic complex (GO:0099545)" and I think this is very appropriate. Moreover, it would be nice to capture the effect of this on synapse development.

comments.species: Paper focussed on mouse brain lysate, brain section, slices and whole animal as indicated in the Figure legends (e.g. Figure 1 B "mouse brain lysate" and supplementary figures (e.g. Supplementary Figure 1 ."...in serial coronal sections of a P10 mouse")  Primate brain section staining described in figure 8 but not used in the annotation.
comments.rationale: Paper characterized PCDH-17 in the corticobasal ganglia circuits with a particular focus on the excitatory prefrontal cortex striatal projections and the inhibitory striatal globus pallidus projections. Utilizing an antibody, whose molecular determinants are not well described, they show excellent specificity utilizing loss of immunoreactivity in western blots, histology and electron microscopy performed with knockout tissue. These antibodies are used in super-resolution immunofluorescence and quantitative immunoglold electron microscopy to show PCDH17 is concentrated in synaptic specialization at the periphery of the active zone and the postsynaptic density on both sides of the synapse. This is true at both the excitatory and inhibitory synapses. The knock-out animals allow investigation of synaptic function and the best evidence is that genetic deletion leads to a reorganization of pre-synaptic vesicles, which in the paper focuses on excitatory synapses. These morphological data hint at an increase in vesicle numbers and this is consistent with the modest reduction in the rate synaptic depression in the PCDH-17 knock out animals relative to the control.

3. "...Interestingly, a subset of Eps15 is localized to the rim of invaginating vesicles or pits at the plasma membrane in stimulated shibirets1 mutant boutons...

comments.species:
Perfusion fixation: For electron microscopy, the rats (n = 3) were deeply anesthetized with Equithesin (0.4 ml/100 g body weight) followed by intracardiac perfusion with 10–15s flush of 4% Dextran-T70 in sodium phosphate buffer (pH 7.4) followed by a mixture of 4% FA and 0.1% GA in the same buffer. Small (0.5 0.5 mm) blocks from CA1 were freeze substituted, sectioned, and immunolabeled as described previously (Mathiisen et al., 2006). For double immuno- gold labeling, the sections were first incubated with rabbit polyclonal anti-PICK1 followed by goat anti-rabbit coupled to 20-nm colloidal gold. The sections were exposed to formaldehyde vapor at 80 C for 1 h and thereafter incu- bated with rabbit polyclonal anti-GluA2, followed by goat anti-rabbit coupled to 10-nm colloidal gold. The sections
C. Haglerød et al. / Neuroscience 344 (2017) 102–112 103
104 C. Haglerød et al. / Neuroscience 344 (2017) 102–112
were examined with a Fei Tecnai 12 electron microscope at 60 kV. For bright field light microscopy the rats were perfused as above, but glutaraldehyde was omitted from the fixative. Vibratome sections were cut from whole brain tissue.
Electron microscopy quantification and statistical an- alysis. Electron micrographs of asymmetric structurally defined synapses were obtained randomly from the middle layer of the stratum radiatum in the CA1 region of the hippocampus (Schaffer collateral synapses). Images of 60 synapses from each animal were selected for analysis; each showed intact plasma membranes, presynaptic vesicles and a clear synaptic cleft. GluA2 immunolabeling was quantified as number of gold particles/lm (linear density) of membrane length or as number of gold particles/lm2 (area density) for regions of interests in the intracellular compartment in asymmetric synapses.

comments.species: p.2: GlyRa3-deficient mice (Harvey et al., 2004) were obtained from a colony that was crossbred with a transgenic line (GlyT2–EGFP) that expresses the Green fluorescent protein (EGFP) under the control of the glycine transporter 2 (GlyT2) (Zeilhofer et al., 2005). Homozygous GlyRa3-deficient mice that express EGFP are fertile. They were maintained as homozygous breeding pairs (Glra3 /) and served as experimental animals. In all experiments, GlyT2–EGFP (Glra3 +/+) mice served as controls. -- Highlighted 07 Aug 2017
comments.rationale:
Reduced facilitation by forskolin of mIPSC-frequency in GLRA3 KO mice.

8/9/2017 Pim
- Important to note here is that the basal glycinergic transmission (amplitude) in not negatively affected in KO animals. There are even larger mIPSC-amplitude in Glra3 −/− mice at P15–21. This shows that the GLRA3 is not present in the postsynapse mediating the postsynaptic currents. In contrast, forscolin is shown affect IPSC freq (increased SV release) via GLRA3.
- Based on the known transmembrane topology of the protein, the "integral component of ... membrane" term was chosen
